>>6485470
SD, MJ etc. are procedural algos.
Using an algorithm to generate vast amounts of data from a small seed isn't a new thing of course. Demos and videogames have been doing it since the 80s.
The problem was always taking real world data and crunching it down to such a seed so it can be reproduced, but diffusion seems to be a solution to that old problem.
It's a form of compression, just not compression the way you know it.
I also suspect the models don't actually contain all of the data they were trained on.
There's a set of images that were prominent in the training data which the model can reproduce almost perfectly (afghan girl etc.) then less prominent images that are stored less perfectly and then tons of obscure images that barely had an influence on the model. Cull those out and having the model fit in a few gigabytes doesn't seem so outlandish anymore.

>>6485571
>It's a form of compression, just not compression the way you know it.
I also suspect the models don't actually contain all of the data they were trained on.
I mean that just simply not true, you can't reverse engineer a model, go into it and extract "afghan girl by Steve McCurry.jpg" because it just doesn't exist within it even at a lossy level.
The reason you see that image predominantly in generations of (Prompt: afghan girl) is because its a bias within the parameters of the weights themselves (and not the "raycist" or SJW type bias). You can also call it overfitting essentially you've trained the AI to autisticly near copy that image by accident because of how many time that image appears in the training data. Its the same reason hands are difficult for the AI and the lack of perameters (smaller perams the easier bias can occur) the AI has to go by.

Also the language interpretation (CLIP) is actually separate from the image generation aspect of art generation. That too can also be influenced and in midjourneys case they really spent a lot of time dialing in their version of clip for MJ. Which is why unlike stable diffusion its a lot easier to get your desired results without having to get super literal.

>>6485755
Photography uses a tool - a camera - to produce a direct image using the push of a button, after a bunch of setup and parameters. The camera takes the input of light through a lens (similar to a human eye) and near-perfectly reproduces it. Most humans cannot do this, and the ones who can cannot do so anywhere near as quickly.

Most photos are garbage, however. They have poor lighting, no stabilization, the wrong settings (ISO, aperture, exposure, white balance, etc), bad composition, and flood the internet with photos of peoples' pets, food, and their cocks.

>>6485419

1. True that the models, weights, and parameters themselves may not have copyrightable data, the training data used to create them certainly can be protected by copyright. The claim that AI is a form of encoding or compression is not a "retarded myth", as it is a fundamental aspect of how machine learning algorithms function. Additionally, the use of large datasets does not negate the potential for copyright infringement. The datasets like LAION may be separate entities, but their use in creating AI models can still potentially infringe on the rights of copyright holders

2. The concept of fair use and derivative work may apply to certain situations involving the use of copyrighted material BUT it is not a blanket defense for all instances of copyright infringement. The determination of whether or not a particular use of copyrighted material constitutes fair use or a derivative work is made on a case-by-case basis and takes into consideration factors such as the purpose and character of the use, the nature of the copyrighted work, the amount and substantiality of the portion used, and the effect of the use on the potential market for or value of the copyrighted work.

3.Certain forms of expression, such as ideas and methods, are not able to be copyrighted but copyright law does protect certain aspects of a work that may include a specific style or aesthetic. For example, the original expression of an idea can be protected by copyright, and this can include the way the idea is presented or the style in which it is executed. Additionally, in some cases, the elements of a work, such as the specific selection and arrangement of elements, may be protected by copyright.

Why You Should Copy Anime:

Krenz Accuracy Imgs: https://files.catbox.moe/tklkj8.rar

**Strive for quantity AND quality.**

Anime Studying:
>Copy anime references exactly and draw them from memory. Use illustrations, screenshots, anime figures, 3D models, etc.
>Don’t copy recklessly. Use construction, color theory, and other fundamental concepts to rehearse a drawing process that you can later easily manipulate for original artwork.
>Post all of your anime studies. Post even when you’re told not to. Create an art community that actually draws and improves together instead of just talking about it.
>Number your attempts and link to your previous posts.
>Critiquers should lead by example by posting their studies.

General Anime Style Discussion:
>Questions about achieving certain styles/techniques/compositions etc.
>Drawing methods, study habits, resources, tutorials, tools, software, etc
>Be specific and try to post a sample of your study attempts before asking for help.

**Draw copies from good anime styled references to mindfully up our mileage, internalize appealing aesthetics, and learn from each other’s processes and knowledge.**

Recommended Resources:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6434940
I think 600 likes for 2k is a very good amount. Theres people with 10k who get less than that.
The usual tips are the same as always, drawing OCs from larger users, try nsfw, fotm, keep posting a lot and such. You are already improving as you keep drawing and posting new content, your followers notice that.

I think the luck factor is very important. Being in the right spot at the right time. How do RTs from big accounts work for you? Do they get lots of likes/follows? If thats so, aim for that.

Me personally cant grow by my own anymore as Im shadowbanned. I draw nsfw, not hardcore stuff though, just nudes. Everytime I post something new, my tweet gets hidden for at least 12 hours. It isnt showing in the search option, not by keywords, neither tags. I rely just on my own followers and luck. And even my own followers dont see my posts most of the time. I have 3k, but only getting 30 likes or so because of this. The moment another account RTs me, I can reach 3k likes. Thats really awful and discouraging.

I wish there were other places for promote yourself instead of depending 100% on that.

I dont remember right now in previous versions, but you can press 'P' as a hotkey for the color picker

>>6451775
When Im first sketching a scene it looks kinda similar, its my style. But its been months since my last big draw. Think that I sculpt with my pen in ZBrush, so Im basically drawing in 3D, rotating 360º my figures and adjusting them on every angle, they need to look fine.

Creating 3D scenes instead of 2D, allows me to do many other things, like rotating over the scene, animating, scaling specific parts, changing the pose or working with cloth/fluid physics.

But the main reason for using them in interactive scenes inside Unreal is for example changing their clothes with particle effects, different hairstyles, or anything you can imagine inside a videogame.
Im still polishing my scenes but Im planning to make them downloadable with small minigames and such

posts.com:
>>6473866
Never saw that drawing, but the torso looked blobby to me, and the belly looked rather concave because of the values you used. Also the hips seemed a bit iffy to me. Pic has the value shapes you used in red and blue is the implied form. The belly definition was just my personal preference. You can blur the abs and it wouldn't really matter. About the light, here's a tip, when you compare the rgb sliders of an unlit area and a lit one, and one of the sliders moves in the opposite direction of the rest, there's something strange going on. The exception is when the lit area is the shadow area of another light or when you're straight up changing hues. This is not a hard rule, but something to think about.

What is /ALT/?
If you're looking for a place to post your cartooning then you've found the right general. This is /ic/s 1st and only merged hub where both Eastern and Western stylization can coexist peacefully, hence the double title.
>Rules & Guidelines
(1) Any form of cartooning is welcome; so submit and receive feedback from others. (2) Please resize your images before posting. (3) Share your knowledge and (4) Remember to not be afraid of asking for critique. Most importantly, keep discussion at a civil level

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The more you understand something, the less likely you are to fuck it up. If you have a feel for the sizes of certain bones and mobility of joints, you'll be less likely to mess up limb proportions or have body parts bent in ways that they cannot. Even during observation knowing the skeleton (and muscles) will help you. Learning the skeleton is part of understanding the "why" of the human figure, and like with most things, shit is easier to understand, remember, and reproduce if you can grasp the underlying fundamentals and not merely memorizing results.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6485326
Copying a skeleton in detail isn't helpful. But it is helpful to learn a simplified skeleton, like the one taught in "Basic Human Anatomy" by Roberto Osti, that gives the overall forms, proportions and alignments, because 1) parts of the skeleton show just below the surface; and 2) you will need a basic skeleton you can draw quickly to facilitate learning the muscles.
Also, the skeleton is very important in understanding and drawing the joints, especially knees and elbows.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: You don't. You probably won't ever overcome it. But that's okay. A lot of successful artists who are really good at their craft still doubt themselves in their work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Start small.

Don't expect whatever you put onto your canvas or page to be perfect or even good. As someone who is learning, be easy on yourself, and experiment. Even go aa far as trying different media. I got bored with the tedium of drawing in pencil, scanning the bits,cleaning them up in Photoshop, and assembling them into panels to do my comics,and discovered Second Life,a place built entirely by its user base,and it hypnotized me for half a decade. What simple Photoshopping skills I had served me well, and I made fantastic things doing simple texture manipulation. Mandelbulb flowers, crystal grass,animated paintings and lava hot tubs. These skills that you struggle with in traditional art mediums may flourish in others,especially the new 21st century kinds.

>>6483529
What do you mean by "style of perspective"? Two- and more-point perspective was avoided by almost all artists until mid-seventeenth century.

"The remarkable feature of angular perspective is that, although it was well-understood by geometers such as Pélérin (1505) and Vredemann de Vries (1605), it was avoided by virtually all artists until the middle of the seventeenth century. Aside from two paintings of doubtful attribution painted around 1440, the first successful use of full angular perspective was by Dutch artist Gerard Houckgeest in 1650. (There was limited use of the angular construction in floor tiling throughout the period, but this could easily be achieved by connecting the corners of a one-point perspective grid, and did not require an understanding of the rules of two-point construction.) Inspired to develop a radical design for his painting of the tomb of William the Silent, the king whose efforts united Holland in 1581, Houckgeest turned to Vredemann’s architectural representation technique of the oblique construction for the interior of the church at Delft. This dramatic shift from the unremitting one-point perspectives of the church interiors of Saenredam and Neeffs gained Houckgeest immense popularity in The Netherlands, but it was to be another half-century before the two-point construction appeared in Italy in the hands of Canaletto."
https://www.webexhibits.org/sciartperspective/raphaelperspective6.html

>>6479090
procreate is garbage pushed to trend chasing normalfags
it used to be ok, but it’s been shit since 4.0 with bugs out the ass, retarded interface for the new features like adjustments which also can’t be layers and have retarded meme “alternatives” to, lacks basic fucking shit like sampling lower layers, and a dysfunctional brush engine that made some of the best old brushes behave like shit
like sadie’s (from the op) best sketching brushes no longer work because THE FUCKING TILT HAS BEEN BUGGED FOR 3 FUCKING YEARS AND PRODUCES ERATIC NONSENSE ON THE FUCKING DOWNSTROKE with size compression on even their own default brushes do it, they just hide it with a noisy stamp and texture, pic fucking related

for the ipad, the best apps are
CSP (lol sub)
Artstudio Pro (basically photoshop minus the high level photo editing)
Infinite Painter (low layer ceiling, even lower than procreate, also on android but idk if it’s the same)
Paintstorm Pro (fucking amazing brush engine, but drains battery like an absolute bitch)
Realistic Paint Studio (same devs and engine as paintstorm, also a bitch on the battery, but limited and tailored for a more sketchbook experience to the point they didn’t even let you color pick from a ref before the normalfags started whining)
Affinity Photo (basically photoshop with a lot of the high level editing, but kinda shit to draw/paint in because of shitty input interpretation, like brushes start as if you pressed hard for one stamp, then switch to what you actually did, but haven’t touched it in a long while)
Adobe Fresco (was barebones but maturing rapidly, haven’t touched it in a while, lacked basic shit and went out of its way to not copy every other app, resulting in a shitty basic UI)

CSP and ASP are the best hands down, ASP takes all PS brushes (except live/3d brushes), both abr and tpl, both are very productive without a keyboard and have full key customisation, I like ASP better

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483080
You can work out foreshortening using a geometrical method called parallel projection. It entails first drawing a simple view, then projecting parallel lines from various points on the figure at a desired angle to construct a second view. Sometimes, as in picrel, one or more intermediary steps are required to get the desired end result. Picrel is from Jean Cousin's Livre de Portraiture, which contains many examples. You can also find a few simple (one-step) examples of this method in Burne Hogarthe's Dynamic Figure Drawing. It shows up mostly in older books, though.
Note: This method does not give you size/camera distortion, only foreshortening. For the former, you need to set up a picture plane and have your projecting lines converge towards a point representing the eye of the viewer.
This is all fascinating but I don't recommend it. When it takes more than one step, it's an enormous amount of labor; furthermore, it's difficult to predict the end result. It is better to work intuitively and train your eye to what looks right. If you insist on perfect accuracy, using a 3D model as the basis for your drawing would achieve the same result and save you a lot of time.

>>6483080
>I know there's a scientific mathe formula

well if you really want to torture yourself...

Bruce MacEvoy's Handprint has one of the most comprehensive explanations of perspective anywhere on the web:
https://www.handprint.com/HP/WCL/tech10.html#index

Wade Meyers is an aviation artist who uses descriptive geometry for all of his aircraft drawings & renderings. 2d plan drawings are required to construct objects this way. You also have to already understand the basic mathematics of perspective in the previous link to understand anything he's saying:
https://www.wademeyersstudios.com/book/1774/perspective-projection-by-descriptive-geometry-a-manual-for-the-artist
There are other introductions to descriptive geometry but this one is made for aviation and vehicle artists specifically.

Willy A. Bartschi's "Linear Perspective" book gives you an history of linear perspective, its applications, and also the "circle of view" method.
https://archive.org/details/linearperspectiv0000bart/mode/2up
I think this is the best introduction to formal perspective.

But like everyone else in this thread is saying, technical perspective is going to give you a headache if all you want to do is construct foreshortened figures. It would be much easier just to learn the basic freehand perspective that everyone teaches.
This stuff is really only necessary if you want to create technical drawings, drawings with really accurate measurements, industrial design, architecture... etc.. but in those fields descriptive geometry has already been superseded by CAD and 3D software which do all the thinking for you.

posts.com:
>>6484333
No problem. It is good to know these things, because technical perspective applies to more than just 2d art. 3D software runs off of the same mathematical foundation, and photography is a quite literal representation of the projection plane and camera, so the same composition techniques apply.

Like >>6483111 was saying, distortion and foreshortening can be achieved with technical perspective techniques. Remember that you can change your field of view in the same way as you can with a camera.

The "circle of view" method of perspective described by Bartschi is also incorporated in a more digestible form in Scott Robertson's "How to Draw," he calls it "cone of vision" but they're functionally the same thing.
Here's a youtube video that summarizes it: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RsbzCHLsQuQ

Regarding "How to Draw," later in the book Robertson decides to only do the tedious method of subdividing squares diagonally over and over again to build forms in perspective. Just doing perspective projection with plan views for complex forms would have been easier. Do that instead for hard-surface shit.

I don't think people are "hiding" any secret technique on how to foreshorten. Art education in technical perspective collapsed after abstract art, and then descriptive geometry suffered a massive blow when CAD and 3D software phased it out of higher education (Back in the day architecture schools had professors solely dedicated to teaching descriptive geometry).

Most people are only capable of teaching lazy methods of foreshortening because that's all they've ever known, and without any accessible knowledge on the subject people just brute-force their way into it, iterating over and over again until their perspective or foreshortening looks sound. And because they've never been taught any technical knowledge, they have no vocabulary to describe what they're doing, so most "tutorials" just boil down to
>yeah just uh make it bigger when its closer

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6478013
I am also a late starter. I started at the age of 29 and even went to art school after. The difficulties are mostly psychological in nature. I was already established in my field, made good money and was regarded as a high achiever in things that required a logic/math oriented mind. Starting out people chuckled at my trash art, they saw it in contrast to my wagie achievements and also even felt safe to shit talk me, because "I could take it right?".
Things got worse when I went to art school to try to become pro at some point. The school itself was great, and I didnt mind meeting younger people better than me, it was actually a blast. The bad part are family, partners, friends who actively discourage you "from throwing your life and talent away". This continues to this day, I am 36 now and a decent artist. Yes I don't earn nearly as much as I did, but I am happy and don't feel depressed anymore. Still get offers from people in STEM "to come work" with them. It's meant well, but I can't help but feel hurt by the fact that the people closest to me think what I am doing is kind of a joke and they are still waiting for me to "snap out of it" and get a real job.
Just be prepared to find new art friends and be humble again. You will go from high regarded normie to nobody overnight. You will most likely not get support from the people you think who would, even worse you will get discouragement throughout. This, paired with the fact that you will have low confidence at first (because you are bad and even young kids are better than you) makes it incredibly hard to make it. Good thing is, it's all in your head, it's a psychological challenge, the neuroplasticity crap is bullshit, I caught up to everyone quickly.

>>6479322
I will tell from my expirience. I've been drawing since childhood. Didn't go in artscool or art classes. I drew cartoons, anime, some of my fantasies. My classmates thought that I was good at drawing, my parents also praised me. I thought I was good, when in reality I just drew like a child who loves to draw. In each class there are at least 1-2 such children. You know these guys, or maybe you were them.
With age, I began to draw less and less, by the age of 18-19 I drew maybe a couple of times a year.
But one time I needed to draw pictures for my text rpg, and god, I realized how shitty of this i was.
This caused me great pain, never in my life i hated and despised myself more.
So I took courses in academic drawing and painting. I was 27 at the time.
Now I'm 31 and I still continue my education. By no means do I claim that I am a good artist now, I am not even close, but I see my growth with each work.

So, in my opinion, drawing as a child gives only two good things:
1. Fine motor skills develop.
2. You go through the drawing phase for fun as a teenager.

The first catches up very quickly, in just a couple of lessons you will already be good friends with a pencil/stylus.

The second point is what breaks many adult beginners.

The realization that before you start drawing your fantasies, you have to go through the hard and boring part. And it may take years. Those who have been drawing since childhood already had their fun. They have drawn cute anime girls, robots, disney princesses and monsters.They understand that it will not get better. And they will have to suffer. And accept it more humbly.

All this, of course, does not apply to those who studied in art schools as children, and then continued their studies in art at a college or university. These guys are gods and we will never catch up with them.

You don't have to suffer for art. Suffering happens because of perfectionism, usually. All you need are minimal expectations and to roll with the problems.

The idea of "Acceptable Tolerances" is also something many artists could learn from.

Additionally, if you say "art will be suffering" or "I will never catch up" or other stupid bullshit, well your brain goes "ok" and you won't. It's self-sabotage.

Some people use pain to motivate their art, some people use anger. But when you lose motivation and sanity from self-flagellation, when your "suffering" is a detriment to your art, then it's time to rethink it.

>>6481180
It doesn't stagnate, rather it forces us to face a different reality, which in turn changes how we do things and what we make.
Using AI vs not using AI is a deliberate choice now, whereas art in the previous paradigm had none. The simple act of someone declining to use (or choosing to use) AI directly in their art says something - however WHAT it says is dependent on the context around that person. In my case, for example, I just detest the process of painting. So AI has almost no use for me beyond references, ideas, and similar indirect usage.

It's like how images of real things can be photographed or made by hand. The choice to use a machine to take a picture is what many people do, but landscape artists (painters, illustrators and more) still do what they do. Digital vs trad also is a similar situation.

My gut tells me that a lot of artists feel like old school draftsmen when CAD took over, but I really don't think this is the case - they're just suffering brainrot from immersing themselves in demoralizing, misanthropic, propagandistic takes about humanity on the regular. So when this came around it was like lighting that angst-fuel on fire.

craft paint is probably useless. just use a limited color palette of the medium of your choice.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6484165

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483868
india ink can be a lot of different products. some have no binder, some have gelatin glue as binder with the lamp black in colloidal suspension, some have shellac as binder in a weak alkaline solution, and maybe some even are based on whatever dye. the ones pigments can stay without binder because the particles are very small or also because the particles have some tarry residue. they are usually waterproof or claim to when dry but often not completely. i don't see why in the case of gelatin or shellac binder since gelatin dissolves with enough moisture and warmth, while alkaline salts remain after the water evaporates.
acrylic ink is more waterproof when dry. it can dissolve with alcohol.
you might see more differences if you use them with other media.

>>6396806
Soft shading/lighting with fewer steps. Gotta tweak the airbrush settings because default airbrush settings are often bad. If you use CSP, consider getting the “airy airbrush” tool. You can get similar results blocking in color on a higher layer then using a soft eraser, but a good airbrush will do that all on its own. Imo, it’s an essential tool for ani semi-realistic soft shading.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6463841
I got in the industry by founding my own gaming company with colleagues and being employed there with an artist role. So not really your typical way of getting into the industry, but definitely one with the brightest future I would say. Would recommend over chasing jobs and clients your whole career.
But if you want to get into the industry, don't send the same portfolio to dozens of clients. Tailor it to their needs, show them that you want to do the "dirty" jobs as well. For example, if you want to do concept art, don't just put up flashy images of soldiers (they got enough people who want to do that) but rather lots of concepts for mundane objects that will fill their game world. But really, it depends on what kind of industry you want to get into

>>6483035
What this anon posted >>6483087 was what I was talking about. Here's what was always copypasted to back up the image:

"Fundamentals before anime" is a kind of sequential thinking that creates artists who simply can't draw anime. You can use anime to study your fundamentals. They aren't mutually exclusive. You can also study realism and anime simultaneously.

Pic related is from the foreword of that popular アニメ私塾 book by a guy in the Japanese anime industry. See the triangle?
>上手い絵の模写: 上手い人の絵の記号(絵のパターン)を手に入れる
>Copying good drawings: acquiring the symbols of skilled people's drawings (the patterns of the drawings)
>実物の線画化:実物を理解することで、上手い人の絵が理解できる
>Real life drawing: by understanding real life, we can understand skilled people's drawings
>創作活動全般: 落書きや作品制作
>General original creation: sketching, complete OC works etc

Quote from the foreword:
>こうして、学生時代は「自主制作アニメを作る」「上手い絵の模写」「実物の線画化」のトライアングルを繰り返すことで劇的に上達していき、絵を描き始めてからわずか3年でスタジオジブリの入社試験に合格することができました。
>In this way, I made extreme progress during my school years by repeating a triangle of doing my own original anime drawings, copies of good drawings, and life drawings, and only 3 years after picking up drawing I was able to pass Studio Ghibli's employment test.

He was 19 when he started drawing.

Pic related also shows drawings from before he started practising deliberate copying as well as his original anime drawings from ~2 years after that.


Thus ends the copypasta. All this is to say, it's not the "Krenz" method, and if you see someone referring it as such you would do well to gently correct them.

>>6482660
Western animation used to barely use shading. Ever since shit like Megas and Boondocks they realized "oh fuck we can add shading like the jappos???" and now you have this thing where the jaunty, constrained "action show" western syle of making things actually move is blended with that style of cel shading and it looks really fucking bad.
Like there's no flow to it, you see it with all the netflix crap because it's a lazy way for them to add depth to otherwise stiff poses and actions.

A TRUE "western-anime" would be like the OG CN Teen Titans or The Boondocks. Avatar is a few layers removed from those but I'll count it as it's closer, I guess.

Funnily enough though, a lot of anime from the past decade moved to using LESS shading, either going with more of a flat style or just keeping it subtle. I'm not sure if some of that is to mesh with the use of 3D models cleaner or just a stylistic choice, but it still looks good and really emphasizes how the actual movements and flow are better than things like that anon posted.

The MOST timesaving thing for a comic is skillful layout and planning to shove all the budget into a few choice panels people remember, while minimizing the work you need to do in the less-important ones.
Same way Berserk was drawn when it was regular. Most panels are designed to be made FAST and errors are accepted if they're within tolerance, it's the big shots that have all the effort put in.

Also having assistants, using premade assets, tracing, etc all help.

>You have to be successful in order to have influence.
This statement is factually wrong. The work doesn't need to be successful to be influential at all, all it takes is for somebody who sees it to take some of the good ideas and apply it to their own thing. You may only KNOW about this influence because the thing that was influenced became a success, but the influence is there regardless of either work's success. A complete piece of dogshit that nobody liked can be highly influential if somebody took the things they liked from that thing, made something of their own with those ideas and that thing was highly successful and spawned copycats of its own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6486204
You're conflating teaching with influence. If a teacher's student becomes successful off their learnings, then yeah they totally do get to say that they TAUGHT that successful person. INFLUENCED is a different concept.
No, somebody who made something unsuccessful doesn't get to claim responsibility for the success of a future work that is influenced by it, because they played no part in assisting the successful person. Nobody said that they should be able to "claim credit", nor did anybody imply it, so I don't see why you jumped to that conclusion.
And being able to claim credit or not is irrelevant to the influence this person's work had on the successful work, and neither is whether or not the influential work was successful. The concept of "influence" is an objective one. Person A makes Work A, Person B sees Work A and says "That's cool, I like the way x and y" and goes on to make Work B, with x and y. Factually speaking, Work B was influenced by Work A. Person A can be cool with it, or want to claim at least partial credit for x and y, and Person B may or may not acknowledge it and give credit, none of this actually matters toward whether or not Work A influenced Work B.

posts.com:
This thread is dedicated to master studies, where you copy artwork you admire as a form of study. They are the quickest way to improve and learn about any fundamental you are having problems with. If you need to work on your hands, copy hands from other artists, and if you're having trouble with rendering, make careful studies of paintings with lighting you admire. Studies can be quick or long. You can even copy anatomy books like Bridgman, Morpho, and Hogarth. The type of studies you want to do depend on your personal goals and the types of problems you are grappling with.

Artists of all levels are welcome. Critiques and redlines are encouraged.

>>6466732
I don't think you really understand what the term "master study" means judging by the crap you've been spamming anon.

A "master study" implies you're studying from an artist you consider well-rounded and of a higher, established skill level. You do so in order to break down and understand the process behind the picture, akin to reverse-engineering it. It has nothing to do with them being born centuries ago or having their works on a museum's wall. Even studying someone else's study can be considered a master study.
The medium and style said artist is using only matters to you. If you believe Miyazaki's drawings possess something you want to extract and instill into your own art, then he is a master to you and studying his work counts as a master study. Same goes for some famous Twitter artist you look up to.

Forcing an anti-Japanese culture narrative or pretending to objectify what should be valued as masterful or not in the end just tells more about you people's petty complexes more than anything else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473037
He's showing the front plane of the pectorals. This plane is bounded laterally by a line from the clavicle (specifically, the point on the front at which the clavicle curves backward) to the bottom outer limit of the pectoral (just a little below/outside the nipple). From that bottom/outer point, an oblique line going toward the point of the shoulder is the base of another triangular plane, which is the side plane of the pectoral.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6484528
>bullshit their way
Pretty much. A lot of artists use intuition that they've built up from years of experience in order to purposefully draw certain part of a figure wrong in order to achieve the desired affect. If you place a 3d model in the same position in space, you'll notice that it's going to look different. If you want to get good at extreme foreshortening I sujest first getting good at drawing the figure as a 3d object and then study art or photos which have the foreshortening you want. There's an image pack called Extreme angle I recommend.nmvrwg

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6484390
Yeah, you could user a wider range of darks. You got some nice dark highlights on the beast thing to the right, as well as the hair, hand, and belt of the main demon dude, but it's not enough to make it interesting. It's fine to keep the background with a low value range so it's not too distracting, but in that case you need to make the main front characters have bigger contrasts so they pop against it.
As for coloring, you could start by adding a new layer with some basic colors and a blending mode, and see where that takes you. Look up grayscale to color method.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6484843
There's 2 options:
Start with pencil and paper, since you are already familiar with it from your childhood, so you don't need to learn a tool at the same time you try to learn art. If you later decide to swap to digital though, you'll need to learn the tools and software and go through an adaptation period.
Or, you can start directly digital, which will be harder for a few months as you try to learn and get used to several things at the same time, but if you do get through that process then that's it.

>>6484977
Your line quality is really nice. Although it's a bit overworked on the eyes and nose.
Subtle angles are really hard, you brain wants to force it into a front facing view. It can help to consciously remember this and force yourself to see it correctly. You can also double check in a mirror or by taking a photo with your phone and flipping it. Seeing at a different angle makes the mistakes stand out. For the likeness, get the shape of the head is really important, yours is pretty good. Getting the correct distances between facial features is crucial. Although overall I can still tell it's meant to be Gosling.
This guide for likeness is pretty good.
https://www.artstation.com/artwork/w8yrQO

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6485112
Both. Tracing models and photos helps build proper muscle memory about shapes and lines, while gesture/figure/master copies train your eye. Both skills are just as important, and neglecting one over the other is gonna make you plateau hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6485378
From your drawing, I can tell you seem to at least be putting in the effort and time despite lack of skill, so I'd suggest you pick a book or course and work through it, carefully doing every exercise it tells you to do. Vilppu's book and course (do both at the same time) would help you the most at this stage, but if you want to improve your accuracy you could start with Keys to Drawing. Steve Huston's Figure Drawing for Artists is also a good intro point. If you feel like doing Keys to Drawing might take too long (it really doesn't, it's like a month-ish of an hour a day), then you could look up Dorian Iten's Accuracy guide, it's a single video you can draw along with that will teach you some of the measuring techniques you need to copy more accurately.

In short, you need to work on 2 skills: your observation/copy accuracy, and your gesture/dynamism.
For the former do Keys to Drawing by Bert Dodson, or Dorian Iten's Accuracy guide.
For the latter, Vilppu's Drawing Manual (books + videos), or Steve Huston's Figure Drawing for Artists. Pick one of each, can work through them in parallel so you can use the techniques you learn in each other's exercises as well as your own art.

>>6485934
I can personally vouch on
>keys to drawing
>drawing for the absolute and utter begginer, revised
Both these books should be very resistant to your ADHD as long as you split the book into enough pieces so you dont get overwhelmed. Just two pages per day. If book has 200 pages and you crawl 2 pages per day, you will finish it before summer starts.

If you have mega strong ADHD then print the book and physically take 2 pages out of it at a time so your brain cannot slobber over whole book nonstop flipping back and forth. And just copy the drawings and do the exercises.

if you cannot do even the 1 or 2 pages at a time then i am sorry, you will be forever NGMI and probably end up dying as hobo on street since you will never finish even applying for social welfare. I wish you good luck. You will probably need it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you're having trouble, try posting on other sites as well, not just this one.

Reddit has critique related subreddits. There are discords out there that you can use. Do art daily is a potential place, there's some other more niche sites sometimes but they can be harder to find. Maybe try some IRL classes as well, or sign up for something online that has instructor feedback.

Don't give up, keep going. I got a bunch of nasty comments on /ic/ when I started out too, now I'm at an intermediate level and generally get complimented on my stuff, or will get feedback if I ask for it. When you're a beginner it can be difficult to get targeted feedback because the advice most people will give is 'just study fundies' (e.g. read the sticky, go through the resources threads and do the recommended books/courses). So keep grinding and posting in different places, eventually the feedback will start getting more targeted as the advice people are giving needs to be less broad.

posts.com:
Disney animator Glen Keane claims to have aphantasia. Do you think he, and other artists like him, have true aphantasia? I can certainly imagine that purely observational artists could draw well with aphantasia (in fact I could even see the lack of distraction from mental images to be helpful in this pursuit), but I don't quite get how an artist with true aphantasia could even begin a drawing from imagination. I saw him say that he starts with scribbles and refines from there, but starting with a rough gesture and refining is common practice even for artists who can see images in their mind, and I'd think a true lack of mental imaging would prohibit the placement of even a comprehensible gestural sketch from imagination.

tl;dr Do creative artists with aphantasia truly exist, or are they just full of shit/don't actually have thoughts devoid of imagery?

Hello, I hope I am not being obnoxious talking about my girlfriend again. But she has true Aphantasia (Cannot see any kind of visual memories in her mind at all).
However, she began drawing around 3 weeks ago and I am training her using a similar path to what Krenz proposes.
So far, I am seeing her progress faster than i did (I stand in stark contrast, as I am I can visualize very well).
Things I've noticed she seems naturally better at.
1.Organizing her process, from the steps on going from sketch to coloring to layer organization
2. She seems to have a better hand to eye coordination, has a lot of patience and works well.
3. Takes a lot more care in detailing, fishing, making something presentable
4. She is able to notice details in things that often go over me, as I am often lost in thought, that comes both for observation and general media consumption

I am curious to see her progress, and I'll likely post more about how effective the training is for anyone else with Aphantasia or who might simply be curious.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6475582
Most of us are just executing a procedure here and there trying to bend it toward "what looks good" with trial and error. Sometimes we have a strong idea and try to bend it toward that, but that makes the process harder.

I don't have aphantasia, but I don't have strong visualization abilities, and making visualizations isn't part of my or most other artists process.

I think you have some idealized notion that artists "see something in their mind" and mentally project it onto a page and trace. I'd be surprised if even one human artist on the whole planet does that.

There are artist that *do* have visualization as part of their process, like the late Kim Jung Gi, but another part of the process was building a library of processes by doing drawings from reference of lots of different things.

Draftsman, animators and painters from imagination don't have psychic powers. They just work harder than you and know more than you.

>>6475582
interesting topic. as someone visiting from /x/ I think I have a vague grasp on aphantasia. someone explained it like having a PC running, processing images and all kinds of visuals but then having no monitor connected to that PC. so you know what's going on, you just can't see it on the screen. that fits my situation as well. I do have a memory, I know what I look like or my mother. I just can't project it into my visual field or use my third eye to see it with my mind's eye. I have a friend of mine who can project anything into his sight, we call that hyperphantasia. btw I do have imagination since my "PC is working well". It's different for audio stuff tho. I can hear my thoughts in any voice, imagine music and instruments, sounds and stuff in my head. other senses like smell, touch and taste are less pronounced. I can feel imagined touch to some degree but taste and smell are basically not existent. I do differentiate between the third eye visualization, hypnagogia and dreams. I do dream and I see them just the same as if I'm awake. I do see flashes when tired and shortly before going to sleep. for me that's working alright. but in the waking state I just see black when closing my eyes, I just see black when thinking of a person or an object. I know the underlying concept of it though and memorized the most important details on my mental HDD.

as another anon said here, drawing for me is like starting out on a blank space, knowing what do to in theory, but going in completely blind, building up with each stroke, trial and error, not knowing where the actual drawing goes on paper.

btw some people claim they don't think in words but concepts. also some people can not read a book without moving their mouth to speak the words, because they can't think them in their head. this entire aphantasia thing is to me is so much more than just a lack of visualization. it's the understanding of the workings of our human minds in infinite complexity

posts.com:
The general thread for Manga / manga-styled comic-making, manga-style illustration and related comic work.

Support each other and talk about your work or the work of others that excites you. Inking, character design, paneling / layout, writing, planning, and other discussions are all welcome.
Post resources, questions, in-progress pages, breakdowns of other works, etc. If a work is not yours, credit the maker (unless it's fucking obvious like a full page of One Piece or something).
Thanks to everyone for making /mmg/ a level-headed and helpful place. Remember, drawing and making comics and manga are difficult endeavors, and we're all in this struggle together.

posts.com:
Some western / indie publishers of Manga:

Saturday AM ( https://www.saturday-am.com/ )
> Digital indie magazine, seems to be on the up-and-up
> Open submissions for long-form series; also distributes series currently being published elsewhere.
> Regularly publishes one-shots, making it a good potential outlet for already-finished work.

Noir Caesar ( https://www.noircaesar.com/ )
> Focuses on black (specifically African-American) content, but seems willing to publish anyone good enough.
> Seemingly series-based only.
> No "magazine" style updates; series are updated on their own schedule.
> Seems less regular than Saturday AM, but also seems larger in terms of readership.

Oni Press ( https://onipress.com/ )
> Technically indie, but at this point large enough by comic standards to be mentioned in the same breath as other publishers.

Antarctic Press ( https://antarctic-press.myshopify.com/ )
> Longtime large-indie publisher of OEL / manga-esque books.
> Seemingly taking submissions at present if http://www.antarctic-press.com/html/submissions.php is anything to go on.

Yen Press ( https://yenpress.com/ )
> Started out as a small indie publisher of original / Korean material, and has grown reasonably popular since.
> As of 2016, it is also one of the western arms of the Kadokawa Corporation, with Kadokawa owning a 51% stake.
> Editorial inquiries can apparently be sent to yenpress@yenpress.com, however, they apparently are not open to new submissions at this time.

Viz Media / Viz Originals ( https://www.viz.com/originals )
> *The* western manga publisher.
> Currently in the exploratory stages of setting up an English label.
> Submissions are open and several books have been announced. However, progress on the label seems to be moving very slowly.
> Still might be worth a shot anyway.

Shrine Comics ( https://shrinecomics.com/ )
> Small indie manga publisher
> Seemingly attempting to make the transition to physical volumes
> Allows crossposting to other sites

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479531
Possible? Absolutely.
Feasible? Not really.
Reliable? Absolutely not.

Never rely on a creative endeavour as a primary source of income, especially one that is inherently out of the public eye. Always have a craft or skillset you use as your job, because you'll never be want for job openings. I personally trained to join the managerial staff of a store, which pays better than you'd think even if it really does feel like an entry level job.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479665
For me, I am most productive when I do a big batch of pages assembly line style-I pencil 10-20 pages, then ink, then do shading and effects, then letters.
Inking takes the longest for me. I'm trying to work on making my pencils clean enough that I can skip the inking step but I'm a ways away from that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479670
Yeah I do that as well.
I always think that the reader will look at every panel the same way I do, when that's not even close to the truth.
The average reader will maybe spend 1-2 seconds looking at a single panel.
Obviously, really big panels or something like a 2 page spread will get more attention from the reader but for a normal panel, detail isn't needed.
Also you get a much bigger 'wow'-effect when your normal panels have little detail and look simple and then your big and important panels are full of detail and shading etc.

When I read manga/comics I sometimes spend more time looking at the speech bubbles and reading the dialogue compared to looking at the characters, let alone the backgrounds of each panel.

But I get it. You want to go all out and show what you're capable of, even in normal, boring panels.
Restraining your power level and knowing when to go all out takes practice and skill.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6484257
I'd say no bait and switch, especially not before you get a following. The first page can make or break a comic, and I have dropped many on the first page alone. So that idea not only risks the people who would hate your bait page but love the switch to drop it before they even see the switch, but you also risk the readers who would love the premise from the bait page and lose interest when they do see the switch.

My advice is to show the readers exactly what they're getting. The first page should set up something intriguing, a character or situation that will make people want to find out more about it and turn the page, if they do and what they get is something entirely different, they're likely to leave.

For example, in English a name like “Reginald” or “Bridget” have a certain high class connotation to them, and you wouldn’t name a prince character Billy Bob. Similarly, “Veronica” is a “hot girl name,” unisex names are Tomboy territory and “Brad” is a “stock jock name.”
Its connotations like that that I’m worried about screwing up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6484520
I'm in the middle of a sci-fi drama right now, and one thing I can recommend is having someone from a contrastingly primitive or out of the way environment to be your anchor to the reader. Not because they need a self insert to mindlessly ask questions like an isekai protag, but because they can be the heart of the group who lets otherwise overexposed people take a step back and focus on the world they're surrounded by, which they've become so accustomed to.

Albeit in my case, it's slightly different, since that one more down to earth character is the only human in an otherwise robot cast. But the same idea applies. And yes, it can work. I've been loving every second of this.

posts.com:
>>6485887
I don't know if it'd fit your tone, but you could make the hyperviolence have enough of an extreme bend it takes on a more dark humour aspect. It'd take a bit away from the straightforward "cool" factor.
Having the character act violently unprovoked and employ very over-the-top measures for banal issues would at least make it apparent he isn't supposed to be seen as entirely reasonable.
That kind of behaviour can be weirdly endearing, at least to me, but it doesn't exactly make the character look good. In general, even if you draw a lot of trashy B movie violence that's clearly just plain exploitation, as long as the characterisation itself doesn't paint the character as a 100% rational righteous cool dude it won't come off as glorifying it.
Hell, even when glorifying it is the intent sometimes it doesn't land. Ken is justified in executing any wasteland goons he comes across because those fuckers are cartoonishly evil, but since it's always depicted very gruesomely it takes a bit away from his "sad kind pacifist reluctantly using violence for the greater good" image and makes him seem a bit unhinged. To me it's part of the fun and charm of the comic, but it's likely unintentional.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Would you rather read a colored comic or a monochrome comic? How much does coloring matter in the reading experience of a comic? If it does matter, how much do you notice the "skill level" of the coloring, aka, how basic vs advanced the coloring is?

Also, post examples that prove your point

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6482017
Mostly B&W with flat screentones since this way the inking is what does 85% or so of the work. But that's simply because I don't really like like the vast majority of american coloring styles (mostly talking about modern digital ones), but euro comics are very nice to look at most of the time (Blacksad wouldn't look as good if it was B&W).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6482017
colored is always better but it takes too long so i get why its not the mainstream, dont need to post examples because anyone who says bw is better probably has some form of hypersensitivity

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6482018
As an artist whose tried both, I highly respect artists who can pull off bw. It's actually so much more difficult than colored, because there are so many abstractions and design choices you have to study up on to make it work. With color, it's much more representative of real life.

>>6482022
I'm not actually so sure color takes that much longer. If you look at most manga, there's a huge amount of hatching going on. A page could take 10 hours if a single person worked on it. I guess it depends on the art-style, though.

On top of that, bw comics are much harder to manage assistants on, because you have to create instructions and documents to get them to do what you envisioned. With coloring, you can just hire a colorist, whose sole responsibility is coloring

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Colour adds infinitely more room for fuckups for only a marginal gain, and in my opinion comics with very intricate colouring actually get tiresome to look at after a while. Black and white or simpler colour(like limited palettes or something like Blacksad or Tintin) are much better for the actual reading experience.
Sometimes colour can help salvage readability when the original art was sloppy with composition and values, like some of the worse panels in Jojo parts 5 and 6, but that's the best I can say about those coloured versions. They look putrid. In general it's less unpleasant to sit through mediocre BW, because mediocre colour like digital airbrush or garish webtoon shit lowers the art as a whole, just look at the butchered right version in picrel.
So to answer the question, I prefer BW or simple on grounds of how comfortable they are to read, since they're harder to fuck up and I prefer comics that prioritise the flow of the narrative over making good individual "illustrations"(Alex Ross is a good artist but his comics feel very awkward to me)
Colour can be good but it's a whole new dimension of complexity added on top and if rushed it's often too generic to add to the storytelling, and by necessity if it doesn't have anything of meaning to add to the whole it'll detract from it.

Limited colour is pretty good but there's something to be said for the harsh contrast of BW, maybe paired with some grey values. It's very captivating and a whole tradition in and of itself, even back from the days of oldtimey book illustrations, and I think it's one of the reasons japanese comics are so successful. It makes for very immersive reading, I suggest checking out the bit about colour and BW in McCloud's Understanding Comics. I think it ties into the whole bit at the start about cartoonier characters being closer to meaning and text than they are to literal representations, so BW leaves more room for imagination and thus emotional attachment from the reader. Colour is more flashy and eye-catching to the general public, but it's not like they're a very enduring audience and anyone familiar with comics will be receptive to BW unless they're some capeshit consoomer.

posts.com:
>>6482017
Monochrome.
Color actually impedes the physical reading experience, even though it improves the observational experience. Reading is supposed to be smooth, clear, and quick. Language evolves to be smooth clear and quick. You want to communicate with as much ease as possible, and so the more visual elements you add the more bogged down that communication becomes. Your eyes become lost in the colors even if they look pretty. I feel the same way about black and white comics that use too many greys and too much detail on every page. I consider the best comics to be the ones where you not only get completely immersed in the story, but you're also turning the pages quickly so you don't get a chance to break that immersion or think about anything else. You shouldn't have to pause the story in your head to think "wow how beautiful" unless it's deliberately there for the pacing. You should only linger on a page if that is what the story calls for, like to take in the scenery or gravity. Black and white keeps your eyes moving, undistracted, turning the pages, until you hit a beautiful two page spread with intricacies deliberately rendered to make you stop and look carefully. And whatever you're looking at there, would likely be important.
As for skill level in coloring I don't care. A comic artist is a comic artist. It's a separate skill from illustration. Learning to speak in sequential imagery is a skill of its own that even the most skillful colorist could fail at. All language, including the language of sequential imagery, should be simple and concise. Highly skilled highly rendered colorful illustrations aren't simple and concise, they're just pretty. What you don't include in your art is just as important as what you do include. Manga is popular because people like it. It's just that simple. And they like it because it trims all the fat and focuses on easy visual communication and smooth eye movement, while also making its limited black and white look pretty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Thoughts from someone who has beginner experience with lots of things.

>Pencil
Kino. Nothing beats a regular pencil on printer paper. Limitless medium. Main tool I use, always carry a pencil with me everywhere I go. Cheap color pencil like crayola is easy for quick coloring. Expensive color pencils work nicely with mixed media.

>Charcoal and conte
Love charcoal on newsprint. Use it not only for figures but also for sketching whatever comes to my mind. The effects of charcoal and conte are very unique and I like the look of fluid and gestural drawings in charcoal.

>Ink
Kino. Great medium and so much you can do with just ink and black and white. Both ink pen and wash are nice and I love the smell of ink.

>Oil
So much you can do with it from simple to incredibly complex. The luminosity of paints and the way layers shine through each other is beautiful. A medium that really is fantastic but takes a lot of thought and consideration into brush strokes, colors, temperature, drying time, even how much paint you load to make a good painting. Can start to become very expensive when buying mediums and more colors. Using a few tubes limits the color range you can get as you lose chroma from mixing but I'm pretty sure there are some painters who use translucent layering from pure colors to get bright effects and having layers shine through together without needing to mix colors directly at all that they wouldn't be able to get from mixing. Slow drying.

>Acrylic
Hard medium but a great challenge. I don't like the way colors look through layering but it might be a competency issue. Not as beautiful as oil but acrylic is good for mixed media and you can use different mediums with acrylic for different effects and it dries much faster.

(1/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479847
>Watercolor
Easy for anyone to pick up but hard to get good. I like the look of washes and translucent layers. Cheaper than and dries fast. I have trouble with drying times and the way my brushstrokes look because of it. Love it.

>Gouache
Really bad with it. I like to use it opaque like with acrylic, but you can definitely use it with translucent layers. When I paint opaque with it my brush picks up the layer underneath because gouache reactivates very easily from water, which gives me awful colors, and trying to get around this with a thicker paint stroke makes my surface and layers uneven and thick giving them unintended texture. When using opaque strokes I lose values and chroma so I cannot reach the color notes I could get with translucent layering over the whiteness of the paper, or maybe I just don't know how to mix gouache I don't know. I'm still keen on using it to improve but it is very hard.

>Oil pastel
It's ok, I used it for mixed media once. Gives an unique look.

>Digital
Efficient and easy to clean up. Can reach color notes easily, but I prefer the color of oil paints and watercolor over digital colors and layering. I don't like using digital for lineart either, prefer to use a real pen instead. I don't like staring at blue light and prefer traditional because I'm a tactile person and like the feeling and smell of traditional tools. Digital is great for pumping things out quickly though but trying to spend for than 10 hours on a digital piece is a chore meanwhile with traditional I can easily spend more time on it.

>Sculpting
Worked with natural clay, polymer clay, and monster clay before. I don't like monster clay because of the way you need to heat and dry to use it, the other two are fine. Not good at sculpting but I like it, working with it feels fantastic and I love watching sculpting videos.

>Digital sculpting
I tried zbrush before, didn't like it a lot. I prefer feeling what I'm working with when sculpting.

(2/2)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479669
I use 4B pencils because it combines the best balance between erasability and control of darkness/lightness while also being less smudge-prone and dirty than softer pencils
I use acid-free cardstock from an industrial-supplier because it's the cheapest I could find while still being great for my uses.
I use Copic pens as they're refillable, feel better than micron and are guaranteed compatible with markers (future-proofing, haven't gotten any markers yet)
I use a big ancient screenless tablet because it still works great and looks cooler than modern ones.

My erasers consist of a soft dust-free one for cleaning big areas and a magic rub for details. I use an eraser shield for the details and the big area one is too soft for it. The magic rub does this strange "smudge until it suddenly cleans it" which is less efficient for large areas, but it's firm enough to accurately clean the small ones.

I also use a pencil extender to keep nubs working until they're unsharpenable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
metal point; small piece lasts a long time. can do sharper lines than graphite of the same thickness and bluntness. does not break like graphite does. good for hatching although contemporary users tend towards careful modeling. good for underdrawing. generally does not smudge as much as graphite. beautiful brown patina in the case of silver point.

oil; there are different ways to do it that are so different that these ways of working oil seem like different media altogether. can utilize dimensions of contrast such as transparency or opacity, light over dark, dark over light, gloss or matte, textured or smooth, wet or dry layers, to create something with a lot of technical depth. wide range of additives to alter properties.

egg tempera; easy to control for uniform matte surface. durable. non-yellowing. can layer multiple times in a session. easy to clean. good as underpainting for oil or tempera grassa.

tempera grassa; less lifting than egg tempera alone. blending more agreeable than egg tempera. faster drying than oil alone. less yellowing than oil. mix only a small amount at a time or you might waste oil. can thin without solvents. easy clean up.

acid etch printing; less skill required than engraving. good for compositions you want to make more of. possible without a press, using instead a burnisher of sort, but not as crisp or even. most use plexiglass and dry point today. if i was worried about acids, i would just practice metal engraving.

>>6479669
thick leaded pencils, I use the overhand grip, thick pencils lets me sharpen down to make a good point while being meaty enough to not snap

5.x lead holder, able to use vine charcoal without needing to hold it.

2mm lead holder, I like this more than pencils, supports overhand grip but not nearly as 'break proof'

brushes + ink, I love doing ink work

Nibs+ holder, I love doing fine constant ink work

watercolors, I prefer a slit pallet watercolor to markers if I have the time, watercolor just gets me the colors and effects I enjoy easier than markers.

samsung s7+, digital sketchbook, its new and digital art is its secondary purpose.

22 inch huion monitor, my main digital tool

rebelle, fantastic watercolor sim and damn good oil/acrilic
realistic art studio, the best digital pencil if you cant get painter to work correctly
affinity, photo manipulation and I am not paying for a sub
csp, the best digital art tool you can get on pc (note digital art, not trying to fake traditional effects)

news print a2, no illusion that the art will ever last or be worth anything so it helps with 'I am making a masterpiece' jitters

I am probably forgetting some, but thats all I got at the moment.

>>6482037
Np, I also forgot about etch printing and scratch board. Scratch board is pretty simple and works similarly to pen and ink besides focus on negative space and the tactile feeling. Etch printing imo is harder than both pen and scratch board because it requires more visualization of the final result and because you're working with more depth usually with the amount of carving you do and the carving also requires more dexterity and weight than the other two. I also think working with different mediums will focus on different areas you want to practice.

To summarize I think you're working with a poor reference of a woman who's had a lot of plastic surgery.
You won't get a drawing that looks right using her as reference.
The pose is also a little too symmetrical to translate into a good drawing.
You should also avoid those unconfident lines when doing lineart. Practice drawing clean lines in a single stroke.
Hope this helps.

Forgot to mention you should also study line weight.
Lines closer to the light source or further from the viewer should be thinner and vice versa.

yeah this is what I meant ( or at least tried to). where I see many people failing animating by mesh is:
1. only using linear interpolation, so lack of weight
2. using the same images/parts in for the whole
cycle, this limit the expressiveness and force of action.

If you are interested try doing this for the tits and pussy lips have 3 distinct images (idle, pushing max position and pulling min position) use the idle for the most part of the animation and in the finishing the movement of pull/push change the image (and possibly also the mesh and vertexes)

>>6477800
>>6477669
Oh I've seen your art before outside 4chan. Nice to see you here and I'm glad you are working on improving.

On the subject of the hair - you can think of it like ribbons that start from specific points and flow outwards from there. I noticed in your other drawing near the start of the thread you seem to draw it as an outline - try using the ribbon method, or doing it "chunks".

For the bodies, you may need to examine the shoulder area a bit more. The delts feel rather small for how ripped they are and that's probably what's throwing people off.

Specifically for the one I replied to - the male character's arm that's closer to the camera looks smaller than the one that's farther. There's also some issue with the lines of his torso where everything is straight horizontal in line, which reduces dynamicism and can draw attention to the areas you may not want.

The facial expressions look mostly fine to me, that seems like a stylistic deliberate choice. And I do think the girl's boobs are hanging mostly properly.

Keep it up, semi-hyper dicks and muscular characters is a good niche.

>>6460328
To understand the meaning of "Just Draw" one must first understand that the true definition of talent is the ability to learn how to do something well with little to no instruction.

Now that we have that definition out of the way, we can begin with why the "just draw" phenomenon exists and why some people are able to actually benefit from the "just draw" when others seem to find it to be a trap.

Once we understand the definition of talent, we can now see why the "just draw" phrase is thrown around as if it was the most enlightened advice ever given. It is not because it actually works for everyone but rather that it works for anyone who has an innate ability to draw--innate not meaning "born with" but rather a proclivity towards drawing that creates a natural ability to learn things.

In order for "just draw" to actually work, one must have talent in drawing. This talent will allow you to be able to draw for hours and learn from your work and mistakes without any instruction whatsoever--though instruction could never hurt. If one does not have talent in drawing, they must seek out help in order to improve or else they will stagnate as pointed out by this anon: >>6463757

Basically, if you don't have talent, learning to draw will much harder and even if you do end up attaining a certain level of skill, your art will never be as good as most of the worst works from artists that do have talent which is why you have to find a reason to actually pursue art. You have to have a purpose as to why you are pursuing it rather than just the blind ambition of being able to draw le cute animu grill.

The real question we need to ask here is that if you do not possess such talent, would you still continue to draw? That is the real question you need to ask yourself here. That will allow you to determine whether or not to continue or if you should just quit.

>>6471926
>The Process of Drawing
Here we go, I'll try to explain as best as I could.

The difference between being able to perform and being able to teach is based on the understanding on the process of that specific skill. Performers tend to not understand the process of being able to learn something and therefore are the worst teachers in that field. They tended to have received their skill by sheer mileage and have often taken decades to get to where they currently are. As they have not properly analyzed their approach and why they do certain things, they have an intuitive understanding of drawing which only helps them. Basically, performers cannot teach and can only perform. This is where you get the advice to "just draw" because performers tend to be the ones that actually take this advice seriously and tend to get good by sheer mileage rather than anything concrete that you can teach to anyone.

Teachers understand a skill at a much higher level than performers and while they may not be as good as the performers, they will often coach the performers regardless. Note how coaches in sports aren't usually better than the players on the team. (If they were, they'd be mentors not teachers or coaches.) A teacher must have a very high level of understanding of whatever skill they are pursuing as they have to properly explain each and every step--otherwise, they're wasting everyone's time.

For instance, if we were to bring this back to drawing, lets say a beginner creates a drawing. You notice that the drawing is shit but because you are a performer, you can't exactly explain why it is shit. You can say something like, "the forms are off" or the "perspective is off" but you can't really delve exactly as to why the drawing is really bad, much less provide useful resources to practice from.

The teacher will be able to hyper-analyze a drawing and know exactly what the issues are what that beginner to study.

Most people on here are performers, NOT teachers.

>>6472033
Chances are when someone is asking you how they can learn how to draw, especially on here where the entire board is literally dedicated to this one skill, that person has tried to draw and might've even tried to learn how to draw but because they are so new to drawing, they do not understand how to approach it.

Just Draw, to a beginner, implies that they just continue to draw their bad symbols over and over again until they eventually improve. It DOES NOT imply--as others have erroneously said--you objectively look at your drawings and analyze why they are bad. This is not something a beginner--especially those who started drawing late--will be able to do as they do not understand the process of drawing.

Because this is a board dedicated towards the critiquing of discussing of artwork, it was quite strange for me to discover that the only piece of advice that was thrown around was "just draw." When you pursue any other skill, you never hear anyone just say, "just play the piano" or "just sing" or "just code" etc. There are typically well defined fundamentals that even those who literally just started are going to be aware of such as playing the scales as a pianist or learning the absolute basics of coding--though coding is a bit arbitrary to be honest.

It wasn't until I started to draw a lot more that I realized that most people on here don't actually analyze what they are doing. They kind of treat it like a video game where they simply play and play and play the game until they maybe get good rather than sitting back and analyzing what strategies are the best, what their weak-spots are, and what is worth practicing. This isn't to say you focus too much on strategies, obviously there is a level of performance that must take place, but completely neglecting it for "just playing" or "just drawing" is quite ridiculous.

Of course "drawing what you see" seems obvious to those who have the innate talent to draw what they see (or have learned well enough to have it ingrained), but a lot of beginners do not understand this at all, and don't have the talent to discover it through pure trial and error. A skilled weightlifter will think using powerful muscles like your quads and glutes to drive through the majority of a deadlift is obvious, but a beginner with no instruction and no innate feel for body mechanics told to "just lift" will quite likely just limply fold forward and try to lift the weight using their lower back, probably finding the move uncomfortable or painful and generally failing miserably.

>>6460328
since learning takes a bunch of time, the best advice they could give you is trust the years of hard work and eventually you'll see the results.

to get good results, it would make sense to analyze your piece after you've gained enough symbol making abilities and think (not emotionally, constructively)

> "OK, this I lack perspective skills"

this is quite simple to fix, perspective is very tactical, with enough grids you will see where you made a mistake, fix it, remember, draw enough to train your muscle memory and you'll draw buildings in perspective in no time,
if your hand is witty enough you can doodle something abstract in perspective. But to that you need to think with more IQ points,
there are some people breaking down every type of perspective while giving basic overalls on it, then apply into your art

>I don't know how to draw circular, soft shapes

from drawing a lot your hand should get smooth lines quite easily, practice drawing a circle, then lines curving around it, find other shapes from pictures and whatnot, draw a bunch of lines to understand the form, soon instead of blockiness you'll get smoothiness

hate shading? look at how it's done in real life, look at 2 values, thern add a rim light, then maybe really soft shapes with a lighter value, make sure to think how shapes reflect light,
find videos of light traveling across the room, going far and close to the object

you're an artist, and artist observes more than normal people, and if you wanna be a master, you gotta put in some studying into it as well

but never forget this, if you love drawing, you better draw your hands off and "just draw", and we promise you'll get gut

or take things slow, just remember to have fun in it too

>>6472842
>>6471842
A lot of people don't have concrete ideas of what they want to draw, or even what they like a lot of the time. Sometimes this is due to a "copying is bad" mind poison, sometimes it's due to a false idea that to "be a master" means that drawing entirely from imagination is the skill to practice.

In general, though, it's that they haven't made a conscious effort to examine their own tastes to where they have anything to say. It can be a compartmentalization issue - happens with coomer artists a lot, where they filter everything "not sexy" into a different mental box and so put almost no new inspiration into their "sexy art box" on the daily.

It could also be a complete disconnect between what they like to consume and what they like to produce - for some, a motivation to create is because of a lack of met desires with what currently exists. In this case they need to examine LOTS of things to know what to "not" make, which by extension gives them the mental negative-space shape of what fits the criteria of what they DO want to make.

Finally, unrelated to the other two, some people really need ultra basic help. Proper posture/desk setup for maximum arm movement is what is missing when a lot of people don't get how to draw from your shoulder, for example. And "How to use a ruler to measure things while drawing" is another, since some people, again, fuck up their mental compartments and remove all other skills from the "drawing" box. The aforementioned inability to compare to reference accurately (along without understanding that tracing can be a tool to help) is another. These are all things that are even more basic than what people call "Fundamentals," they're the kind of shit that almost nobody teaches or talks about outside of an atelier or private instruction.

Most people outside of this hellhole that are parroting "just draw" are assuming that those they speak with are just suffering from a confidence issue like performance anxiety.

Pic rel

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6477369
To expand on point 2 and 3:
Just because someone likes horror doesn't mean they want to draw horror. They may be consumed by loving horror, but want to draw say - something more like Hamtaro or Sanrio.

But if they absolutely can't bear interacting with those media, then they're in a tough spot. They need to really examine what they like in great detail. A structure that works is a venn diagram:

>What I can do as good as them (for beginners this will be mostly empty, this exercise is repeated yearly or every six months or so)
>What elements I want to copy from them
>What elements of theirs I don't want to incorporate into my work

So to continue the example, they may want to draw cute shit and use bold lines and huge eyes, but with some kind of "implied story threads" that are more like the cute, cozy energy found in drawings people do of POKEMON, not hamtaro or sanrio.
