That's partly why asians seem like gods to newbie western artists. Writing in japanese, chinese or korean requires a lot of precision to be legible else you fuck it up. The very act of learning to write an asian script is training line quality from the first day in school, or beforehand.

In fact if you practice copying kana or hanzi you will find your line quality improve dramatically over weeks vs just drawing boxes or circles. You don't have to know wtf you're writing, just copying as accurately as possible. Focusing on the lines, not the meaning.

I used to have that fear and managed to turn it around. I just accepted w/e I was about to draw was going to be the worst drawing of my life, and realized that's a great thing, because if what I shit out is the worst I'll ever be, it means everything I make after it has to be better. I celebrated awful drawings, because I COULD tell they were mega shit, I could see obvious mistakes, and try to learn from them for w/e I tried next. The scariest thing (which I've yet to reach), is the point where you draw something, and are unable to see anything wrong with it. You see it often on this board, stubborn /beg/s posting deviantart OC tier trash and insisting nothing is wrong with it. If you know you suck, and what parts you suck at, you can take objectionable action.
The more you think about it, the more daunting it becomes, so just don't think and start filling pages, don't give those thoughts the time of day, spite them. When I finish a drawing, instead of focusing on the shit parts and being depressed, I'll go "hey, that hand didn't come out half bad, maybe I am improving" followed by "fuck you, fear of drawing, I finished another drawing, what the fuck you gonna do? huh? you still scared of drawing little bitch? lmao look at me I filled a page with confidence where you couldn't last year, and I'll do it again tomorrow". I take the same attitude towards shitters and crabs on this board. Every time I finish a drawing or study it's another victory against the faggots who tried to demoralize me and get me to quit. Let me now interpret this rather glib phrase Just Draw :

To someone who has never drawn a line,I would advise that phrase,and this simple excercise...on a drawing pad of good quality, scribble on a page lightly in pencil for a count of 1-2-3 and then look at the shapes and see what they suggest to you. Then in pen,draw over the shape,and add to it. This will help alleviate the WhuhTuhDruh symptoms of stupification and apathy. And I would also remind them that what they are doing is Exploring, don't take it seriously, have fun,and discover what you can do.

posts.com: "just draw" is only a piece of the puzzle. you could spend 10 years drawing but if you don't do it MINDFULLY your growth will be slow. some will require an outside perspective or advice on how to improve their weaknesses, which makes "just draw" a near-useless advice. basically it's only good for lazy people who don't have the habit or the discipline. I would add that mindfulness and the ability of learning from your work can be obfuscated for those with specific personality traits but the good news is that a growth mindset can be cultivated. I was struggling with this lack of a proper mindset due to a very bad childhood and all the videos I could find about art were from artists who were supported by their families and never had crushing mental hangups.

>>6481616
Invest in some good quality drawing pads,and one pad of Bristol board. And,for now,black ballpoint pens,and a pencil.

Take the pad,and for a count of 1-2-3,scribble lightly with the pencil. Now see what the random shapes suggest to you. If this squiggle looks like a face use the pen to highlight those marks,and add details of your own. Feel free to draw upside down if the random shapes look promising. And,importantly, know that this is a way to awaken your imagination, and don't be disappointed with your first outings into art,even trying is to be applauded.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483323
A lot of people don't actually have ideas all that often. It's not anxiety or perfectionism about making the drawing, it's that they sit down, don't know what to draw, and then do like >>6483191
Drawing random shapes is still useful, but there is an element of art where you have to actually try to examine your tastes and influences in detail.

A lot of people seem to think that artists just "have to make new and creative art from ideas in their heads" like they have to take a shit or it will build up in them like constipation. But that isn't the reality. You have to really self-examine what you like, why and what elements of those things you like, and what you don't.

References are good, but know what references to keep - SPECIFIC TO WHAT YOU WANNA DRAW - is hugely important. Not "saving every tutorial you find", not "saving a bunch of "royalty free model" shots. IF you want to draw mecha? Save mechanical images. Save vehicles, save electronics, save scifi things. Save manufactured objects. Or don't! If you wanna draw super robots instead, look at things like armor, focus on aesthetics you enjoy and so on.
You wanna draw cute girls? Well you first need to know what kinds of girls you find cute and then make an effort to save those.

To be a good artist requires knowing yourself, your tastes, and using that information to propel your work.

>>6482744 Thank you
>>6482818 Very kind but I'll be 32 soon, drawn all my life but only started painting and studying fundamentals in February 2019. I feel like in 4 years I should have made a lot more progress than this, I was and still am very unfocused with my studying.
>>6482933 Thanks for the critique, you're totally right and my edges are all over the place. I don't really think I'm in a position where I can give you good advice, I have a great art friend who taught me a lot and the best thing I can say from what I learned from him is that you should take light fall off seriously. Values fall abruptly right before the light turns into shadow, it can be tricky to see but once you know it you can observe it everywhere and study the phenomenon (I did a poor job with this too by the way). Also, I prefer using opacity jitter rather than flow and another lesson from my friend was to keep the hardness of the round brush at about 50% most of the time, that way you can paint soft brush strokes by making the size bigger and hard brush strokes by making the size smaller. Don't ask me why but it works. Christophe Young has a great video where he explains this and other important techniques: https://youtu.be/8U_h3fw7VRc

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6428290
>It looks particularly bizarre to have the canvas and wood fins coming out of heavy iron/steel/whatever.
they are iron, on both of my designs, the lines are segments, but i can see why one could think they are made out of canvas
>also... why does it have regular ship screws?
because its also works as regular battleship if none of the anti gravitational fuel is available, the flight mode cannot be sustained forever too, because of the liquids properties (has to be kept at a certain temperature and mixture with gases to work/ overheating issues etc.)
>Show pipes or... something to differentiate from regular hull
i think its pretty distinctive from regular battlesip hulls, but i guess it could use more details, proruding pipes arent good for hydro/aerodynamics though., the fuel is highly explosive/hard to obtain aso it wouldnt be smart to have them visible, they are housed behind massive super thick armor plating behind the bublbs under the steering propeller arms, most of the magic is on the inside, like massive stabilising gyroscopes, special pipes and motors for the outside propeller gondolas.etc
also pic relatd are some earlier versions and a regular battleship

It took me a bit to figure out how shade these and show that they are treads on the track, but you need a good underline or if not, dont strictly follow the underline if you know the perspective is off. >>6482653
You can 100% use AI skillfully.
You can use it to make photobash material, you can use it for background elements. You can run things in it via img2img with a high denoise to generate things along a similar "feel" and get new compositions. You can use it to quickly make things that look like matte paintings for animation backgrounds, VN backgrounds, and so on.

Basically it's a free stock asset generator - it takes some learning to get things to come out of it in useful ways, but you can easily fill your hard drive with a bunch of cool shit to reuse elsewhere.

As an artist I can look at an output and go "you know what there's something there, let me give it a shot", similar to how some have used childrens' scribbles as inspiration and reference in order to make cool shit.

Work smart, not hard.

And yea most AI art is crap - the output is shitty, the curation is nonexistent, and the people aren't using all the features in depth enough to shove it out of the realm of "samey AI crap" most of the time. Pure-AI art is way WAY less efficient than other forms, since if you have an distinct idea it's a struggle to wrangle things on target, requiring a lot of generations to get a base and then much img2imging, inpainting, and other refinement to get it to an acceptable level.
That process can't really be improved, only the amount of errors in even simple, generic outputs.

And the reason it can't be, is that all the training data CAN'T be made more "natural" without losing the ability to generate things outside the basics. The more training data there is, the better the outputs usually can get, but as a consequence the more schizo your prompts have to seem to get good results rather than "samey" ones.

That's why I'm not afraid. It's literally inefficient to use to produce final products as it can't be used to do more than boring crap. The market never settles on boring for very long, so artists are really needed in the process still.

Basically this.
Concept art is made to pass on to 3d modellers, illustrators and such so they can do the ACTUAL final product. It's not actually designed as a final image in and of itself, just as part of a larger process, so getting it done efficiently and quickly is really important.
Basically it works like:
>Why draw what you can photobash?
>Why photobash what you can generate and paintover?
>Why generate what you can google?

So many concept artists also paint really samey because if they move from the concept to the illustrator position, they end up doing the other end of the same job. Companies want unified aesthetics and art schools are happy to train people for those jobs. But it ultimately makes them replaceable because they're just there to vomit out someone else's vision and rarely learn to find their own voice.
Plus plenty of art directors are shitheads and don't want them to have their own voice in it, only the director's.

They spent their time doing the easy mechanical work of art and then reveal how shit their personalities are. I don't think they're actually in danger of LOSING their jobs but the field of concept art changes with technology rapidly. The introduction of accessable 3d for compositing, the glut of high quality images online for photobashing (without licensing, as the result either never leaves the studio or is done in very transformative ways to not bother legal) changed it radically to where many had to get used to photobashing as a main component of their work. This is no different, it won't replace them - just force them to learn new skills as it can be useful in getting things done on time and under budget.

>>6483387
The way it works is that the alt text of images is what's associated with the training data. And a lot of that text (it's 5 billion images!) is from shitty clickbait and youtube articles, as well as non-clickbait ones and - most importantly - pinterest. So you may have things like
>J.C. LEYENDECKER | Norman rockwell art, Norman rockwell, Rockwell
incorporated into the data from peoples' pinterest collections.

As >>6483273
put, you need to autistically analyze each prompt, possibly each keyword, as well as the weights and so on in order to get it to do what you want.
Putting "rockwell" in the negatives may have undesirable effects as well. The reason for this is that you're trying to direct the image generated via averaging out all the data using the text prompt for any particular seed. So putting Leyendecker in the prompt and Rockwell in the neg may just cause it to be confused since both are showing similar humanesque shapes. You may instead need things like specifying dates due to Leyendecker being active before rockwell was - 1919, 1911, etc as tags may help.

I learned that you have to approach it like this just playing around with it while doing other things, because puzzles are fun and there's a several-minute timer between generations which dovetails nicely into a workflow.

A good example: Peanuts. On a pure skillcel level Peanuts isn't impressive, but the simplicity reflects the content. As Charles Schulz aged, the line became shakier and the art cruder. But that was fine, the comic was a reflection of the man. Could you imagine if Schulz used AI to do Peanuts?
Another example is my favorite, Robert Crumb. He fearlessly puts it all on paper. His insecurities. His sexual fantasies. His obscure interests. His bizarre philosophical thoughts. His fucked up childhood.
Now Crumb IS technically skilled. But he also has a quirky style—an acquired taste—which is closely identified with him and his content.
Theoretically you could have an AI that does the same. It could have an entire biography, psychology, individual art style. But at that point we’re just playing pretend. What human would care? (besides the odd tech fetishist)
When the dust settles humans will still want art from humans, and it comes down to content. AI is a novelty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6484485
A chef stealing his ingredients is necessarily depriving someone else of the use of those ingredients.
Training AI models on art is done by the training program simply observing the images. There is no removal of access to the images by the training's use.

Comparing them by calling it "theft" is wrong, which is why there are arguments about whether or not it's infringement. We artists do not have unlimited domain over our art - we are allowed to reuse art without permission in many many cases, but the total of those is summed up as "in order to make new art" - copyright is to prevent both copying and ripoffs of individual pieces. It is not a ward of protection against competition.

>>6484526
It's "observing" because it's analyzing the images and writing a tiny portion of information about the images. It is not copying the whole images into a database or otherwise keeping them around.
That's why some idiots insist it's "learning like a human", they're wrong in the detailed sense, but the meaning they have is that the AI is only keeping tiny bits of data "about the image" instead of the whole image, which is totally fine for people to do unassisted.
Heck you could likely take photos of other artworks (outside the Richard Prince type of this) using heavy camera filtering to only get scattering blocks of light and it'd still be fine to use that as a base for other art.
Which might still be more data than AI uses out of any individual image.

I long trascended fear and anxiety.

Tough the techniques that would fix your personalities permanently take too long to explain and apply, you can default to the Mind Trick, of which I should publish an article one of these days.

It's simple and it's something that everyone is familiar with, though nobody but me appears to have understood its nature.

Ever learned to ignore tickles? Stop shivering from cold? Stop sneezing?
It's all one single state of mind, and if you engage in it you're basically choking off some brain processes temporarily for so long as you maintain it.

Why am I mentioning this? Because another effect is that you cannot feel emotions in that state.

I tested many times, and I can guarantee it. If you also have the ability to trigger any emotion at will, you can also try and come to the same conclusion. They're mutually exclusive.
So whenever you start feeling panic attacks or other unnecessary feelings that lead to loss of control, you now know what to do.

Shit tier. Or at least that's the trauma left by my mother.
It's antisocial and non-performative, if you're down on your luck and need money or something, you can go to a subway station and sing or play the guitar, but you can't paint or doodle and have people be interested.
Even those fuckers who make cartoons of people need the people to sit there, and can only do at most two costumers at a time.
If you play music, or public dance or do comedy or magic, do balance acts, etc. people will just surround you and those entertained can just give you money.
In all of those cases, both the result and the art making are part of the performance for the public, for a drawing you just sit and draw while the "public/costumer" sits there bored out of his mind as you hope he likes the drawing.
>Anime
>Waste of life
>Video Games
>Low tier
There are dozens of reaction channels on youtube doing nothing but watching and reacting to anime. Most are floundering and earn no money? duh, but the fact that there's more popular channels than others means there's something performative entertaining the viewership who are giving money to them to feed the illusion of a parasocial relationship.
And for video games, there's a whole site to watch people play games that earn millions each day.
Is there a lot of risk and for many, not any earnings? Yes, but is low effort.

Drawing is high effort, low earning, anti-social, and boring and soon enough obsolete thanks to AI, which unlike any of the above hobbies, the AI doesn't need to learn to emulate charisma.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6480028
Not weird... or if it is weird its a good deviation from the norm, an advantage.

Used to be similar to you.
You likely find putting your brain to work, doing stuff and creating enjoyable. With videogames you put your brain to work and make something inside that digital medium, is it something actually useful in any capacity when you log off? nah, But your brain liked putting in the effort and making that super complicated raid farm in Minecraft or even things that do not remain inbetween sessions like winning a game of CS:GO or whatever the fuck. You could argue videogames trick you into putting effort into a black hole that will never spit out anything, but you could also argue that if you have fun the time isn't really "wasted".

Anyways, this is a good thing. Do not get addicted to scrolling reddit or some consumer "hobby" (happened to be during the pandemic sadly).
Managed to quit reddit entirely but the addiction to scrolling still shows up in one way or other way. But it seems to be getting much better recently for some unexplicable reason , returning back to my original , restless self (still pretty lacking in energy but there seems to be progress). Maybe its better sleep or not trying to turn everything into "productivity' and turning everything into a grind like main stream self improvement tells you to do. Counter intuitively, like a chinese finger trap, I seem to have more fun and be MORE productive when I do not try to be productive.

The only thing I could pin-point the improvement to is:
-Stopped watching as much self improvement content
-Had a pretty big period of self-indulgence when it comes to scrolling and it felt like shit, but without the "muh productivity" backround guilt that is basically backround chatter. Causing my brain to seek out more "active" hobbies subconciously, almost as if my muse is starting to come back from the dead.
-Stopped using stress/fear as a producitivty tool (mostly because it stopped working as such)

>>6470632
refine the chin placement it follows a rigid pathing make it follow some sort of smooth arch it'll look more natural that way
the bangs have a nice delayed action to them good job : D
also i'd suggest drawing the ears as well even if they're just place-holders cause they'll help keep the head shap from warping with each succesive frame
hold the looking at camera frame for longer before transitioning into the forward leaning motion also make the head a bit farther back in that frame or push it slightly forward in the final pose cuz if you're leaning forward you bend forward slightly rather than rotation forward while being stuck in the same location
also do the eyes completely open first and add the blink after you've smoothened the movement
i get the vibe you're going for but i think you over-stepped in that bit
as is anime eyes are already notoriously difficult to place properly since their orientation depends on the camera angle rather than some defined points in space

you have long way to grow young grass-hopper

>>6470942
>>6471023
>>6471012

I make 95K a year doing storyboards in the US.

You have to stay within the confines of the script, there are times when you can make some changes but you have to pitch it to your superiors so it goes you > director > supervising director > showrunner/execs. If your change makes it all the way through that multiple times it probably will stay in through the final.

We do a lot of previs here in the US so shot composition, and fight choreography. but it depends. A lot of board artists in the US like to do almost key animation because there isn't a huge budget for retake animation.

I will say that you don't HAVE to be a super good draftsman to be a great board artist. But if you can combine good drawing skills with a rudimentary level of knowledge of animation and shot composition you will never be out of a job for more than months at a time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471069
do you have a lot of free time outside of work to make comics / personal projects? How busy are you when you are actually in the office? (like, how reasonable are the deadlines?)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471081

Yes and No.

Storyboarding is not a 40-hour-a-week job in the sense that. It requires such a command of so many different skills some of which have nothing to do with drawing; Time Management, Shot Comp, Animation, and Draftsmanship hell if your gonna make your storyboards you need to have editing know-how. So realistically you're gonna be working 50-70 hour weeks.

But there's a catch. A good one I might add. My schedule is roughly 10-11 weeks per episode. We turn things in and have to wait a week or two for notes and this process happens about 3 times after that 11-week deadline. So sometimes we are sitting on our hands or helping other teams on their episodes.

So if you make sure to hone your time management skills you can have a bunch of free time. But when we are working it's intense, but it's kind of made up for on the back end.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6471102
It's okay man, I lurk here from time to time but I only answer questions that I view as sincere. So don't worry about it.

I don't feel trapped at all, storyboarding exposes you to so much that when you're doing it you can't help but improve. I'm only a few years in but I know people that maintain a comic and board. The thing is that there are a lot of opportunities to move up (some people get in through nepotism, but not all), and with moving up comes a significant pay bump. I'm talking about being a Director (120-195K a year), but it also comes with more responsibilities and that means those 50+ hour weeks just went to 80+ hour weeks and on top of that YOU are responsible for how the animatic turns out, so more stress too.

I know people who just hit that 10-year mark, they are all mostly directors by then, and if they aren't they are just board artists that are paid well because they want to protect their time because they want to do what you wanna do. It's a balancing act, no one can tell you what to do. But the only way you'll know is if you commit.

Can I ask your career path? Was your first foot in the door as a storyboard artist? Did you do internships in studio before getting a fulltime gig?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6473076

I started as a revisionist, I didn't finish school. I got more and more opportunities as time went on. Like I said above, there's no correct answer besides actual boarding. I know it's kind of a meme but everyone's path is different and you will never know until you commit to a path of action. I'll say this about portfolios, everyone says you should have 2-3 different pieces with action and drama, etc. But that's not necessarily true. I got hired off of a few action poses and one board. So In my experience, I would say focus on making boards and composition but also focus on life drawing and figure drawing, I mean actually sit down and work through the phases, lay in, contour, values, and finishing. A few hours a day thumbnailing for boards, and a few hours a day life drawing will take you insanely far. By the time you get around to finishing a board you will be better than you were. And on top of that if you always thumbnailing you will have a bunch of thumbs that you can draw upon to make into full boards in the future if you want to. it's a win-win. Also, learn Storyboard Pro as well as you can in school if you have access to it.

All I have ever wanted to know is how much politics actually play a role in the animation workplace.

/co/ makes it sound like the entire industry beneath the corporate level requires you to not only hold whatever "current thing" left wing values are the new hotness, but also to demonstrate or signal that you're an ally in some way. Meanwhile twitter appears to corroborate this theory by the way big name animators behave and the things they celebrate online.
I know this kind of question is the sort of thing a bad faith /pol/ user would ask to stir up off topic discussion, but I'm genuinely curious about the real experience. I can't seem to get a straight answer from anywhere about it, it's all polarized and embellished.
To clarify, my personal positions are spread across the political spectrum, I don't know what I would particularly categorize myself as. But the one thing that keeps me from trying to get into animation is that I don't want to be forced to put on an act and celebrate each and every left wing position just for my peers, lest I be ostracized or scapegoated or whatever else. I would love to just keep my mouth shut and draw, but the online left wing world suggests that silence is in itself some admission of being an adversary. And if I were ever asked a loaded question I wouldn't want to have my reputation quietly tarnished just because I answered neutrally instead of being unequivocally supportive.
I'm not convinced that working in American animation can be separated from the current state of politics. And if that's the case I'll stick to blue collar trade work.
I'm aware of the bias on this topic. But maybe someone in this thread can give me their honest experience.

Sorry, forgot about this thread.
>Do I have to say I'm a black trans disabled lesbian in order to get interviews? Will I ever get hired if I'm a straight white male?
They're gonna find out whether you're white or not if you're looking for full-time positions anyways, even if remote. As a leaf, my country is brainwashed on diversity shit, but they still definitely do hire straight white males because they get the job done.

A heads up to anyone applying for jobs: you'll need to be prepared for some level of an interview and an art test. On top of a phone interview, I also had to do in-person interview or a Zoom/Google Meets interview. About 2 or sometimes 3 rounds of them. If you get more than 1 interview, it's a good chance they really liked you. Shit is tiring but easy as fuck to pass as long as you don't act like an asshole or someone who sniffs their own farts. Always ask questions at the end of the interview.

The art test is usually to see if you can match their in-house style and to see if you were bluffing in your portfolio.

Try looking into your local job listings and make a LinkedIn account to apply to more listings found in your country/city. You may have to move countries or cities if you live in bumfuck nowhere though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6456218
I had a similar issue and it might sound retarded but try going the exact opposite direction and take some time aside to do whatever you think would be the most miserable, unfun exercise. For me that was copying a Bargue plate. By the end of it you won't have burst into flames and even if it takes way longer than it should've or looks horrible it's not the end of the world and you'll have gotten something out of the experience.
After doing that I became progressively more ok with the idea of doing studies even though I used to be super averse to the very idea of drawing copies since you're going through all that trouble just to reproduce something that's already there. I understood the value theoretically but had no fucking patience to subject myself to it. Sitting down to study and analyze a picture can actually end up being really fun, specially if it's an artist you like. To me this was unthinkable because the only way I had fun before was making shit up and tossing the drawing as soon as I got bored.
Just pick one thing and stick with it, the more you do it the more used you'll get to it. For me, at least, the problem was that I was too used to drawing mindlessly as recreation so studying felt unnatural and scary. It's just a matter of getting used to something unfamiliar.
Again I know it's retardedly simple but I think it's the most reliable solution. Just be consistent with it and eventually the aversion will be gone. You'll always have plenty of time to draw your own stuff for fun, and it'll expand your options.

Art as a profession is something one should take joy in otherwise while the skill may remain, the soul goes away. Art as something for yourself doesn't need to worry about it, and if you don't enjoy it, much as I hate the word, you're just being a poser for likes and (You)s.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6451437
Practice, simple as.
When I did go to an art school for a bit, I went in expecting to be amongst titans, but I still ended up being a big fish in a small pond, mostly because I've been drawing for longer than most have been alive there.
You just gotta do it over and over again, until eventually you can internalize steps and externally "skip" them, so instead of doing the rough skeleton, your able to go straight to rough details and all of that.
At one point I just went hard mode and exclusively used ball point pen to draw, so no pencil roughs to erase later, just try to make it look good in one go, results turned out to about pic related.
Just practice practice practice

>>6472119
Find the gesture, and exaggerate it. say their torso is bent to the right, and they are in sort of a ( shape, exaggerate that, push their hips more to the left, and the top torso to the right. I think I might be too dumb to learn perspective.
I'm practicing perspective to learn to draw scenarios according to Dong Ho Kim's Space Drawing Perspective book, at some point it tells us to practice with real photographs and try to identify the vanishing points and practice drawing it.
Easy enough, I can put the vanishing points at eye level and sketch the general scenario, but when I'm trying to add detail, I realize that there are objects in the scenario that don't fit the existing vanishing points, and rather they seem to have their own, so I must have missed these vanishing points at the beginning, and then I get overwhelmed. Am I inherently retarded, or what am I doing wrong?

For example, picrel, it immediately jumps to me as a one point perspective, squarely centered, that's why I chose it, it was easy, but then look at the chairs on the floor or the bench near the camera, if I try to draw them in this one point perspective they become all wonky, so there's another point I'm missing, so I put another point in the horizon, but now the whole piece has two perspective points, so it must be a two point perspective, but now then the scenario becomes wonky if I try to fit it.
Or is it that there's TWO one point perspectives? How does that happen? Am I overthinking it?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6481188
In that picture with the table im sure youll find that theres three points of perspective. Yes there can be more then one and thats our reality. The first perspective you lay down is more or less the bases for the hallway and the other two perspectives are helpful for the furniture. Because furniture does not always align with the first vanishing point
Im still a beg when it comes to perspective myself and the confusion is part of the learning process. I cant find a pic that truly shows what im trying to say but I found one that shows two points indoors. Indoor perspective is tricky.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6413837
So Copic itself is a brand. I'm not sure if it's the OG alcohol based brush marker, but it's basically the standard. I would have recommended Prismacolor last year if you didn't want to splurge on Copics, but I think they're discontinuing the line since I've been seeing them on major clearance at every art store. With that being said, you could easily get a good deal. I personally prefer Copics over all of the alternate brands (Ohuhu is my least favorite and I think they give Instagram/YouTube artists free sets for the good reviews because they kinda suck in person). If you want new, you can buy them for cheapest on Blick. After Christmas, you'll see a lot of sets for sale on sites like Mercari and that's where I got mine for a really good deal. I like that Copics are refillable, and they get a lot cheaper to use when you're refilling them. Other good Copic alternate brands I like are Kuretake and Tombow (make sure not to accidentally get their water markers). Hope this helps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6423644
read 'drawing lessons from the great masters' by robert beverly hale.
practice drawing cylinders and spheres until you can draw them in such a way that they're so good they look like an optical illusion. drawing cubes is to condition your mind for perspective so you should do that as well. by practicing these shapes, your paintings will take on their nature. as an example; if you drill proficiency of spheres into your artistic ability, you will be automatically better at drawing breasts.
the book i mentioned will teach you the fundamentals so that you are well-quipped to navigate the various aspects of art. it moreso teaches you how to think like an artist, rather than simply telling you what to think.
you can already do hands better than ai so at least you've got that going for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460515
It's good that you took the time to finish it. Think of the first parts of the drawing step as being more important to the final work than anything else. Check all of your proportions to your reference, and when you aren't sure about something then you'll know what gaps in your knowledge you have to fill in. Be very careful not to simply copy what you see without thinking about it, as you'll grow very fast by being mindful of what you're doing. Keep finishing your painting like you've done here, and enjoy it. Keep sharing it with us.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6460526
With the grid. I just draw the important outlines. the pencil lines would be as detailed as this pic from google. Important contours such as the clavicle would also be marked with a line.
I take advantage of the very fast drying time of acrylic paint, I can just slather on colours without regard if it actually matches the reference image and I'll fix it on subsequent layers. This is why I prefer it to oil.

Soz bro, either you've been scammed or you're mistaken, oils never dry this fast no matter the medium. The oils always win on unprimed paper not the other way around. I like your technique

That said, other anon is right, do a few value exercises to warm up first. You seem to get lost along the way somewhere. Which is interesting bc I also see a sense of focus and order, especially palette wise.

So I'll keep it short:
> values
> edges
> foreground/background. Try to find a way where I can squint my eyes and differentiate between the two
> detail. this overlaps with foreground and edges

You seem to be well aware of your recurring mistakes so I think you'll be fine. I'm pretty confident everyone has their own personal Achilles heel tho. Hope this helps

>>6480078
Thank you.
I'll post the palette that I used for anyone who's interested in figure painting.

Titanium White
Crimson
Burnt Umber
Raw Sienna
Yellow Ochre
Naples Yellow
Light Olive Green (Wallpaper in the background)
Ultramarine (To mix with Burnt Umber to produce black and darker browns)

Brand
Liquitex Basics or Artist's Loft (Cheapest legit art store paint).

Mixing is done on the fly on a glass palette with the same brush used for painting, no palette knife is used. A 1 cm angular flat brush is used for the body and face. A larger 1-inch flat brush is used for the background.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483722
You're overthinking it.

If you try to get to a pro level, then you've got a few interesting options already, just pick one, use it a few times (10, 15, not twice), weight its pros & cons according to your personal tastes, and eventually try something else.

Otherwise if you just want to have fun, just pick any and enjoy yourself.

Regarding the warm ups, try warming up the muscles involved: draw a bunch of lines, a few circles/ellipses, make sure your eyes are "connected" with your hand.

5/10min should be good enough. Some people warm-up for longer: for instance, they'll do a 30min/1h random figure drawing. But usually, those then spend about the rest of the day drawing & painting, so a more extensive warm-up makes sense.

>>6482485
going digital is one of your problems, not that its digital, but because you have no idea how digital works.
1. use an anti-aliased brush, as in a brush that is pure pixels
2. stop using gray or black to shade. when you drew that first one did you shade with a gray marker? no? of course not, they dont exist, you shaded by having the same value, just more vibrant and deeper, not blacker.
3. stop shading entirely, shading is a beg trap and is its own study.
4. work on line-weight, notice how in your first drawing there are bits of intense thick lines and parts where its nice and soft, your new one has all the same line, and its all not working.
5. stop sketching, first draft is the final draft.
its like your raw shapes are fine, its just that nothing else is working with it, the boots and legs are nice, you just botched it all with that grey half-assed coloring and trying to emulate le nippon artists instead of trying to draw what feels good. anime is a solved medium, either fall in line or make your own feel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6485581
If you do digital it affects how you can use the keyboard/mouse and what keypads you can use.
If you use a Rhand mouse then there's less time between putting the stylus down to grab it for adjusting things (this can be fixed using a trackball or dexterity for rhanders though.)

Hotkeys for and such are more designed for rightys' offhanded use so you will need to remap them to the other side of the keyboard to avoid weird wrist issues

Other than that probably not

you are completely wrong, mixing any two colours in any medium desaturates the colours, that’s what the colour wheel demonstrates, what you are describing is simply a matter of pigment following RYB and light following RGB, giving them different complementary colours, ie mixes that result in neutral grey
in RGB blue and yellow are complementary so they produce grey, in RYB yellow is complementary to purple so mixing those produces grey

either way, you are not going to blend two complementary colours into one another in any realistic scenario, so as I already said, it doesn’t matter

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Experience with pencils of different grades, applying smooth consistent values with your pencils, knowing where to pull with a kneaded eraser, an understanding of perspective and forms, a firm grasp of value structures, experience and time. Essentially... rigorous application of the fundamentals.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6485761
Makes a huge difference. Pencils aren't expensive anyway. You can get the essentials and it shouldn't cost you more than $15 in total.

As the other anon said though: it takes a firm understanding of pretty much everything. Lots of practice. Start with just shading drapery, or general anatomy, then work your way up. Otherwise you'll likely overwhelm yourself by starting something extensive and ruining it.

posts.com:
The only advantage Wacom still has in the screenless tablet market is build quality, and even then that's the least of your concerns outside of XP-PEN loose nib, which Huion and even fucking Ugee have fixed.
And with Ugee the only concern is fast wear and tear, outside of that while it works, it works as good as any intuos, but considering how goddamn cheap it is that's hardly an issue.

And that's what this Wacomfag doesn't understand, nobody questions that Wacom is still the best drawing tablet maker in the market for a whole list of reasons. The question is if Wacom's worth the price, and the answer has been a solid NO for at least 3 years.
Why pay 200% the price at times for a 10~17% improvement in quality from the nearest competitor, which in most cases it barely affects the actual drawing experience, and it balances out in life expectancy of the product anyways?

>>6471222
>Are they worth the exorbitant price tag?
Depends on what you're looking for. The Cintiq Pro 27 is the most natural feeling tablet I have ever used in some 20+ years, where working on it really removes that nagging feeling of having to double check your strokes before you make them thanks to how accurate marks are to your intent.
For the average person that can barely hold a pen to begin with and thinks that making 1248 wrong strokes but ctrl+z'ing after every one of them until they get the "right" stroke, no you probably won't be able to appreciate the difference.
But if you work with analogue mediums regularly because of how responsive they are and miss that when moving to digital systems, yes you very well might find the latest Wacom gear worth the price.

The biggest/newest wacom/huion/xp pen you can find 2nd hand. This is the option I would go for personally, but some people are weird about used stuff.
If you want mobile, you might be able to find a used 3rd gen ipad pro for that, and can definitely find a used 1st or 2nd gen + pencil for under $300.
If you need new, a refurbished kamvas pro 16 is about $240, or a refurbished base model 22 (antiglare screen protector instead of etched glass, and worse color gamut compared to the pro or plus) is $280.
If you don't want used or refurbished, kamvas pro 13 is $280.
I've never personally tried ugee or gaomon so I don't know how good they are, but their 16" displays are both $280.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6479265
I would suggest just getting one of these bed desks and see how it works for you first, make sure to check the dimensions before buying. A portable desk you can fold and slide away should be useful for your small living space either way.

If you find it too uncomfortable and would rather spend the money, then your options would be a galaxy tab s6 ~ s8 / ipad or some kind of surface laptop.

A display tablet that plugs into the laptop can complicate the situation, and be uncomfortable to move around with from all the cables and the larger size, especially if you use a lot of hotkeys and still need a keyboard.

I'd really try the desk first and worry later. Better is subjective, people have been making art with whatever tools they have available for ages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Why is tablet so much more difficult than paper!?
posts.com:
Holy shit, drawing on a graphic tablet is MASSIVELY harder than drawing on paper. Making clean lines is almost impossible.
On paper, I can easily do perfect straight lines and circles, and I rarely have to redraw lines more than once; on tablet everything looks like it was made by someone suffering from Parkinson, and I have to cancel and redraw almost every line at least 3-4 times before I nail it.
>"Dude just buy a screened tablet!"
I did it, and though it helped a little bit, it's still a huge disadvantage compared to paper
>"Dude just draw on paper, and then retrace it on tablet!"
Not even that helps! even when I have an already pre-made drawing, the pen just refuses to follow it.
I dunno how to explain, it just feel so "slippery" it's almost like trying to run on ice sheet covered in oil and soap.
Does anyone else have this problem?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6484965
1. make sure the screen and tablet are matched in ratio. If the screen is 16:9 but the tablet is 16:10 it will feel weird. You can usually change the "usable area" for the tablet to match it in the driver and then put a piece of masking tape down to mark the new margin for yourself
2. The sensitivity of each tablet's pen pressure is different, because manufacturing tolerances. You have to adjust your pressure curve in your program's brush settings, usually into a sort of flatter "J" shape to both stop the jitters at the low end and not require huge pressure to get the top end (which can strain wrist).
3. The actual brush texture can matter. If you're using an ultra smooth hard round brush it can feel like slippery shit, but making one that's got some more "graininess" to it can feel better. If drawing in MSPaint, oekaki tools, or drawpile with the pencil tool feels better then this is it. I can't explain why but it's something I had to fuck around with myself to get it to work nicely. The tablet texture itself didn't matter (and I actually prefer a smoother finish for my hand)

posts.com:
While we all know this stuff doesn't matter, I find nice sketching tools add a lot of fun to practice sessions. One of my favorites are the Sailor Fude pen, Pentel Sign brush pen and my favorite mechanical pencil is the Pentel Graph for Pro. Post your favorite sketching tools.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6474228
I’ve gone through several phases of ‘fun pen’

many years ago I liked the 005 micron because it was so fine, and felt sexy to use. But it is completely impractical to sketch with because the nib wears down so fast.

Then i upgraded my paper from cheap copy paper to heavy smooth card stock. I was super into the 01 micron, until I discovered the plastic nib PN micron. The PN is super robust, and you can get some line weights with it. It draws fast and is my favorite sketching pen.

I used the PN until a buddy got me into using a 2mm lead holder with HB lead. Now for quick sketches I use the lead holder and went back to cheap copy paper. The toothy paper feels really good with the pencil.

Recently, I went back to the 005 on the smooth copy paper for some studies (pic rel). The 005 felt just as good as I had remembered, but you really need to be purposeful and you can’t just dick around and make scribbles or the nib turns to a nub.

Here is the list of pens I thought I would like, but find infuriating
>pocket brush pen
Fuck this thing. It’s too slow, the line weight is nice, but the ink is so thin and weak, I’d rather use a dip pen. I also hate the wavy hand tremors that show up when i draw with it. Definitely not for sketching

>dip pen
The worst pen. The learning curve is just way too high. I spent 2 yrs trying to ink with it. It’s even slower than the brush pen because you have to clean the tip and dip every 2 minutes. Then wait for the ink to dry so you don’t smear it. Probably the most unfun pen I’ve ever used. I never have a good time inking with it. The ink is either too thick or too thin or the nib is worn, the ink splatters, and my desk is covered in soggy ink soaked tissues like I just jerked off a swarm of squid.

>>6474798
I am using the gold zebra G nibs and talen’s india ink.

Getting the ink viscosity correct was insanely difficult. My nibs would also pool the ink on them so they wouldnt draw and it would just whiff blank lines on the paper. The only way to get around it was to clean the nib before each dip. I end up throwing more ink in the trash than on paper. Now i have this ink preparation ritual where i leave the ink in an open shot glass for 4 days waiting for it to achieve the right viscosity, and I check on it every day to see if its the right thickness.

Maybe i will try the kuretake black instead.

Pens:
>Faber Castell B, SC, and SB
Pretty great brush pens, although SC and SB are the most fun for me.
>Kuretake Bimoji brush pens
also big favorites of mine although I use the biggest brushes the most.

If you're into sumi-e or want a lot of variety in line width while inking then I recommend giving them a try. I especially like to sketch in these when I'm feeling a little mischievous.

Pencils:
>Pentel 0.5 mm (205)
Pretty cheap and fun to make more precise linework in. Feels really sharp. Use this the most for practicing more technical work/studies.
>Mitsubishi 2B pencil
I love to sketch in this the most, especially for thumbnails or more gestural work. It's smooth like butter and feels great to draw in. Though they get pretty small fairly quickly due to how soft the lead is so I definitely recommend getting a pencil extender if you buy a pack (I just use General's)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Obviously, skill has a role because I don't like this "period blood art" as much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Alternative pigment resources ive experimented with:

1$ dollar store (dollar tree in particular) sells sunbeam brand batteries that are filled with black pigment. Break open the battery and then that can be added to water to create a black ink. AA Batteries (in the usa at least) do not contain mercury.

> The average alkaline AAA, AA, C, D, 9-volt or button-cell battery is made of steel and a mix of zinc/manganese/potassium/graphite, with the remaining balance made up of paper and plastic. Being non-toxic materials, all of these battery “ingredients” are conveniently recyclable.

The black color comes from the graphite. Remove the rod in the center of the battery. I have used this method to produce a brilliant ink and never suffered any adverse side effects.

Yellow pigment can be obtained from tumeric, but beware it stains everything and anything yellow it touches!
Pink can be gotten from dyed benadryl tablets, which dissolve readily in water and have nice color. Also 1$ at dollar tree.

Reddish brown = ibuprofen tablets, blood

Green = certain pine trees needles can be rubbed to produce green streaks, or chopped up into dust using a blender/coffee grinder.
Also matcha powder / olive oil

White = chalk

Forget to mention black can also produced using the ends of used matches or burning a stick.

Dark brown = coffee grounds or tea

The rest i haven't tried but found through some googling:

Blue – blackberries, blackcurrants, blueberries
Red – beetroot, rose petals, cranberries, strawberries
Yellow – mustard powder, pumpkin, bee pollen

All pigments can also be bound to the yellow egg yolk, which can be separated from the white by simply cracking the egg over a paper towel and letting it roll around on the paper towel. Eventually, you will end up with just the yellow yolk and then take the last step and puncture the inner yolk juices into a small cup and discard the rest. use as medium for pigments.

posts.com:
>>6484770
Drawing daily helps you to improve and building this habit helps to get hours in. Once you've created the habit, taking a day or two off isn't the biggest deal in the world. For things like art, a super strict schedule isn't ideal for most people. You'll need experiment to find what works for you. People here act like you will lose all of your progress. Just be careful not to let the break extend for too long. Taking a deliberate break of a specified amount of time and getting back into is much better than ignoring your urges to rest and then burning out completely and ending up taking weeks or months off. Most of the time after a short break I actually come back with a noticeably improved.
Also, instead of taking a complete break you can try a different medium, method, subject matter, environment etc. It helps to change things up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483995
Because comics require a high level of competency in every facet of drawing from composition to perspective to figure drawing, etc. And then it also requires competency in sequential storytelling. Even that’s not enough. You need to be good at writing as well, a whole nother skill. This includes dialogue crafting, plot outlining, etc.

Anyone can just draw a picture. Why do you think so many people get stuck in world building hell or worse, OC hell?

Of course, there’s simplification which can make things easier but you still need some degree of proficiency in the above base skills to make the whole thing work. You don’t have to be a master -just capable.

>>6476156
I've been a professional illustrator for 20 years now.
I used Photoshop for around 10 years for my work. Besides that I only tried other software for fun (Painter, PaintToolSAI, etc.).
When I started to work on some comics related projects I decided to try CSP (Still called Manga Studio at the time), because a few art friends said it had nice tools for drawing line-art.
It was love at first sight, because of it's pencils/inks brush engine and the feel of the brushes. CSP has the ability to use your stroke speed as a line thickness modifier and it allowes me to rotate my canvas (photoshop introduced that feature later on but it's crap to this day), which at the time was a game changer for me (check pic attached). Photoshop simply couldn't compete anymore for natural/traditional looking line-art.
At first I still used Photoshop for coloring and painting my line drawings, but then I completely moved away from it and fully switched to CSP.

CSP pros (vs Photoshop):
- much better line art brushes and engine
- canvas rotation (photoshop with his inertia thing is total crap)
- better color mixing brushes
- better perspective and ruler tools (out of the box at least)
- more stable (I haven't used Photoshop seriously in almost a decade, so this might have changed)
- cheaper

CSP cons (vs Photoshop):
- doesn't support modern multi core processors (when I switched to CSP back in the day, this wasn't an issue, since Photoshop was a resources consuming always crashing mess)
- more limited for custom brushes that involve painting

posts.sub: Schizo take on social media feedback
posts.com:
So I just post stuff I've occasionally drawn on insta for the sake of it - who knows maybe it hits the right spot for someone else. I also follow a few people whose style and art I really like and sometimes express it through an appreciative comment, a share and sometimes join their art contests. Couple of them are big-ish i.e. 10k+ follows or something and they seemed to welcome this feedback to the point where they follow me back, "like" my work and sometimes we have a chat about the community and art or whatever. All cool. Nice.

The issue begins when I start getting praise comments/feedback from them. Of course feedback is nice, sure. Everyone likes getting that nice uplifting comment. But I really value genuine feedback.

Recently I've come to think the positive feedback/messages I get from those artists are just forced back scratching with no value. I may have no following and thus they probably try to support, but this support sounds fake to the point where it feels condescending.

Like, you don't give a shit about my art, why pretend? I don't draw things you care about. I'm no striving artist. I'm just an average joe pinup animeshit artist to pass my time.

I guess you want to get it off your chest that you've "now supported me back" since I went up your ass, but now it has an opposite effect. I don't believe anything they say anymore. It instead hurts because in the beginning I thought shit was genuine and I had actual artists liking my work. I gave up and disabled comments/shares. I'd rather get nothing over bs.

So did I hit a shit community corner where children are indoctrinated to hugbox or is this the norm I'm too stupid to understand?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6482249
It is up to you anon. The advantage of time limit sketches is that it forces you to simplify the drawing to the basic shapes thus teaches you to look at the whole drawing at once and try to get the basics down by the time limit. Your sketches will look trash but at least you are focusing on the basics since you do not have to spend time with details. It also trains you to plan your picture better because you only have so much time you need to make the most of it and doing it constantly over and over trains you in efficiently approaching the picture with a plan instead of just wondering where to even start.

In any case if you are beginner stick with a more easy time limit like 5 minute sketches and then then narrow it to 2 and then 1 minute.

Doerner's Materials of the Artist and Their Use in Painting with Notes on the Techniques of the Old Masters, Revised Edition (1934). Everything you need to know about oil painting technique and indeed fresco, distemper, casein paint. If it ain't in Doerner it's probably suspect.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>6475977
Note that much of the old techniques for making your own paints are toxic as it involves using pigments made from oxidized/mineral forms of heavy metals, so you may want to avoid that step and just use modern paints.

HOWEVER! A large portion of the old art derives from people like Durer, who did write books about it.
The short answer is:

Math. Lots. And lots of fucking math. Medieval math, but still math. There's a reason why the term "Renaissance Man" means someone who is a combination of artist, scientist, craftsman and mathematician - Da Vinci isn't the only example.

i wouldn't completely trust writings from 18th to 20th century when it comes to oil painting materials of old masters. for example the use of resins throughout, many of which were not available or used by old masters. and because their paintings are in worse condition than old masters.
if you want to paint in a more 19th century method, that's a different issue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6472850
Da Vinci's treatise on painting?
https://www.gutenberg.org/files/46915/46915-h/46915-h.htm

Painting back then was in its infancy; its teaching is much more "recipe-based" and less systematic than it is today ("if you want to paint that kind of stuff, then do this and that"; Cennini is a great example of it).

For instance, back then, color wasn't understood as hue/value/saturation. Such systems aren't perfect, but they are incredibly useful to handle colors. My point is, even if you aim at studying ancient techniques, don't neglect modern refinements.

If you are a /beg/inner or /int/ermediate in art, please use this thread to post pieces for critique or ask for advice.
Use this thread instead of making new threads or post in the drawthread with fundamental exercises.

RESIZE YOUR IMAGES TO ~1000 PIXELS wide using one of the following methods:
1. screenshot the image and post that instead
2. change camera capture settings to something smaller
3. send to computer and resize in MSPaint

READ THE STICKY:
Completed: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1uwaXKU7ev6Tw_or__o8ARpUb6r2rCZYJGqwSFV9AD98/edit
New collaborative sticky (anyone can edit): https://hackmd.io/UMnZVhNITW-T2wZpHw6d0Q
Old: http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-draw-learn

RECOMMENDED BOOKS FOR BEGINNERS:
Read the sticky

TRY TO BE ACTIVE AND GIVE PEOPLE SOME FEEDBACK.
When giving feedback, avoid vague "advice" - point what's wrong and try to give the anon you're quoting a clear direction to improve their art (study heads < watch THIS VIDEO about head structure, read THIS SECTION of THIS ARTIST'S BOOK, etc).
You, feedback seeking anon, should also try to be clear and concise when asking for critique/help. When posting your artwork, say what you want help with, and what's your goal with the study/artwork.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>6483210
So you can see how simple the drawing actually is.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Copying is generally better, as you have to focus more and will be more likely to commit it to memory. On the other hand, quick tracing can get you more basic mileage when you're trying to get comfortable with a new concept.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Copying is better because you're actually making an attempt to observe and draw what you see so it practices your hand-to-eye coordination and trains you to learn the process of the artist, it's why mastercopies are a thing.
